A word of caution for these cables.When I need new HDMI cables I don't even blink - I just order them from Amazon. In a general upgrade, I got a new 4K UHD HDR television, Apple TV 4K, a UHD Blu-Ray player, a brand new Denon Receiver, and the new Comcast Xfinity XG1v4-a box that does 4k60.I ordered all new cables because I knew I needed the the 18Gbs speed and wasn't entirely sure some of the 6yo+ cables I had could do that so no big deal. I also need about a 12' run and so I just went with these 15' cables. My first reaction on opening is that they are huge. Massive cables and I figured this had to do with RF shielding. After running all the cables I sat down ready for some glorious HD.All sources were ran to my Denon AVR-S540BT and then my Samsung Q7.To my dismay, these 15' cables resulted in troubles including:-Apple TV running in 4k60 with Chroma 4:0:0 (screen went blank at 4:2:2); 4k60HDR flickered.-Xfinity Box at 4k60 and 4k30 resulted in no picture, needed to set it at 1080p-I didn't really mess with the blu-ray player because I knew I had a problem anyway.I did a shoddy run with a 6' cable and everything worked so I knew it was cable length. So long story short, these 15' cables may not work for your purposes.For those of you interested in what I did, I did research on AV forums and discovered things called Active Cables and I purchased 15' DynamicView from Monoprice. I was able to get 4k60HDR at 4:4:4 on the Apple TV immediately. Oddly enough it only allowed me to see 4k30 on the Xfinity box and I replaced that with a BestBuy Insignia 12' cable and got that up to 4k60.So just be aware that depending on the oomph of your source, these cables may not deliver as promised.

I needed to buy a few new HDMI cables and figured I'd go with these.  I was setting up a new TV (Sony X900E) and Receiver (Yamaha A1070) and was using one of these cables to connect the receiver and television.  I used the 10 foot cable.  I got ARC working and could hear the TV audio through the receiver, also the receiver could show its OSD on the TV.  So both audio and video were working.Then I tried to hook up my PS4 Pro and my Chromecast Ultra (the TV has built-in chromecast but there are issues with Netflix) to the receiver.  The receiver detected them and I could hear audio (from the receiver) but the TV said "no signal".  After going through settings for over an hour with no luck I decided to try a different cable.  That was it, everything worked fine with the new cable and that's the first time I've ever had a bad HDMI cable.  What was the new cable?  The 15 foot version also sold on this page.  That's the only reason I'm giving these 2 stars -- one of them worked.Very frustrating to have it work for (some) audio/video but not the higher resolution content (which is why I bought these "high speed" cables).  Mainly posting this in case someone else has a similar experience.  Don't pull your hair out like I did, try a different cable!

reviewTitle: It almost messed up my tv
reviewDescription: I bought two of these cords one to plug in a Apple TV and one to plug in the roku. The roku one I haven't really tested out because it's in my step daughters room and she's only with us every other week but the one connecting my Apple TV is in my bedroom and I believe it almost  messed up my tv. The very first time I used it i was watching Hulu and the sound went out I thought it had something to do with my tv or the Apple TV, so I disconnected everything and once I plugged everything back on the sound worked. A couple of days later i was watching Netflix and the picture went out everything blurred. I turned off the Apple TV and it still did it. I turned off the tv and turned it back on and still did it. I unplugged the hdmi cable and it still did it. Finally I upplugged the tv and left it unplugged all day, when I finally plugged it back in it finally worked. My tv worked perfectly for a couple of days until I plugged the hdmi cable back in. I watched Netflix for 3 minutes and it started doing the same thing again! I haven't plugged in the hdmi cable again since that happened and the tv is working good. I'm never plugging it back in and never buying one of these hdmi cords again!

The connectivity is stable, and I haven't experienced any issues with signal loss or interference.The cable's length is adequate for most setups, offering enough flexibility for a comfortable arrangement of your devices. When it comes to HDMI cables, it's easy to get overwhelmed by the numerous options available on the market. However, the Amazon Basics HDMI Cable stands out as a reliable and affordable choice. With its high-speed performance and compatibility with 4K resolution and Ethernet capabilities, this cable delivers on its promises without breaking the bank.One of the key features of this HDMI cable is its high-speed performance. With a bandwidth of 18Gbps, it supports smooth and seamless transmission of high-quality audio and video signals. Whether you're streaming your favorite shows in 4K resolution or playing games with demanding graphics, this cable ensures a crisp and vibrant viewing experience. The 60Hz refresh rate adds to the fluidity of on-screen motion, providing a more immersive visual display.The cable's 6-foot length offers a decent amount of flexibility, allowing you to connect devices without any hassle. The connectors are well-built and snugly fit into HDMI ports, ensuring a secure and stable connection. I haven't experienced any signal loss or intermittent interruptions during my usage, which is a testament to the cable's quality.Another advantage of this HDMI cable is its compatibility with Ethernet. It's Ethernet-ready, meaning you can establish a network connection between devices without the need for an additional Ethernet cable. This is particularly useful for devices that support internet connectivity, such as smart TVs and gaming consoles, streamlining your setup and reducing cable clutter.The Amazon Basics HDMI Cable is designed with durability in mind. The cable itself feels sturdy and well-constructed, capable of withstanding regular handling and movement. The black color is sleek and blends well with most home entertainment setups. Additionally, the cable's affordability is a major selling point. It provides excellent value for money without compromising on performance.However, it's important to note that this HDMI cable does not come with any additional features like gold-plated connectors or braided shielding. While these features may enhance longevity and provide extra protection against electromagnetic interference, they are not essential for the majority of users. If you require those additional features, you may need to consider higher-end cables.In conclusion, the Amazon Basics HDMI Cable is a reliable and affordable option for connecting your audiovisual devices. It offers high-speed performance, supports 4K resolution at 60Hz, and is Ethernet-ready, providing a seamless and convenient experience. While it may lack some of the premium features found in higher-priced cables, it more than makes up for it with its affordability and dependable performance. If you're looking for a budget-friendly HDMI cable that gets the job done without compromising on quality, the Amazon Basics HDMI Cable is an excellent choice.

reviewTitle: Good Cable, But Amazon Basics has Joined the Mega Thick Jacket Wars
reviewDescription: This is a fine cable along the lines of all the other mega thick cables out there.  The trouble is, thicker jackets do not equate to higher quality.  Thinner jackets work just as well and are much less aggravating to work with.  The thick jacket and heavy duty plug prevent this cable from fitting into the pocket in the back of my Vizio M Series TV or next to any other HDMI cable in an adjacent socket on my Sony ES receiver.Here is the naked truth about HDMI cables: they either work or they don't, and there is no such thing as a premium passive cable.  There are only 3 possible outcomes with any given HDMI cable:1. Does not work2. Works with artifacts (random white dots)3. WorksIf your outcome is 1 or 2, your equipment does not like the cable, or you need an active cable for a long run.  If your outcome is 3, you are good to go.  There is no higher quality level than "works,"  considering the error-corrected digital nature of how HDMI signals are transmitted.That is a long-winded explanation of why this cable is unnecessarily thick.  Thicker absolutely does not mean more "premium" -- just more difficult to use.  Or, in my case, impossible to use.The last 2 Amazon Basics HDMI cables I purchased were a normal thickness with a normal sized connector, and they worked great.  C'mon, Amazon!  Withdraw from the thick cable wars!

reviewTitle: Great cables if you are buying the 6ft or less version or for non-4K
reviewDescription: Updating my review, I bought this 3 pack and while the first cable worked fine on 4K 60fps signals, the second and third cables has major issues.I had bought these to replace my older AmazonBasics high speed cables (10.2Gbps), however after purchasing a XBOX One X, those cables would not allow the XBOX to work in 4K. I had a similar issue with my Roku Ultra which would not work with the 4K 60fps setting. I decided to try these as they are rated at 18Gbps. While the first cable I tried worked flawlessly (no artifacts, flickering or other issues), the other two did not work as well. I tried Twisted Veins HDMI cables as well and had similar issues. I finally picked up Monoprice cables and haven't had any problems. Most people have good luck with these cables in shorter lengths (6ft or less), however at 10ft or longer I recommend looking for something else if you are using these on a 4K display. The two issues I saw with these cables at 4K 60fps were sparkles or repeating signal loss.

reviewTitle: Careful if considering these for full 4k/HDR
reviewDescription: I have an 4k/HDR Roku Ultra connected to a 2016 Marantz 4k/HDR capable receiver which is connected to  a 4k/HDR Vizio P65 TV. I ordered 4 of these cables (2 in 3 foot and 2 in 6 foot lengths). While all of them would handle plain 4k, none would pass the Roku Ultra 4k/HDR test and if I forced the change, the screen would just go blank and stay like that until a reboot of the Roku. I have never been one to pay extra for "certified' cables as I always thought all cables were the same when it came to digital connections, but with all other options off the table I took a chance and bought a set of Certified Premium Monoprice 18gb HDMI cables. I hooked those up and first try, the Roku test passed full 4k/HDR capabilities, and the picture was fine. I saw some reviews for these cables that said it would pass full 4K/HDR which is why I bought them, but my guess is that some do and some do not. If you want to make sure, spend the extra few bucks for the certified cables. You will need full guaranteed 18gb capability in the HDMI cable for a setup like mine to work. If you only want plain 4k or 1080p, these would work fine. The Monoprice were noticeably thicker and stiffer than the Amazon cables also which to me means a more robust build quality.

reviewTitle: Doesn't handle PS4 Pro with 4K HDR
reviewDescription: Handles 4K HDR from Xbox One S perfectly. Continually flickers in/out with PS4 Pro only when attempting to use the highest video output setting or the auto setting (since that recognizes my tv as capable of handling 4K HDR). Used the cable that came with PS4 Pro instead and it works perfectly. To be fair, it can just be a single defective amazon basics cable or it can be the total run (from PS4 to receiver and then receiver to TV (note: diff brand cable for the 2nd leg of the run that is 15ft and certified for 18gbps)) being shortened by using the shorter cable that came with the PS4 Pro that allows that combined run to be successful. The 4 star rating is because the cable works as advertised with Ultra Blu-ray movies with HDR being output from the Xbox One S at the same run length. It's also a great 4K cable in general as I use it with plenty other devices that don't require as much bandwidth. My current entertainment center setup doesn't lend itself to easy cable swapping and testing of various scenarios so I'm sorry I can't rule more out but I wanted to provide some level of warning for those of you have a similar setup: PS4 Pro to 4K HDR capable receiver to 4K HDR capable TV.

reviewTitle: Cable works fine, but the plastic grip at the ends of the cable is thicker than most
reviewDescription: The cable itself seems to work fine. But the cable casing is thicker than I expected, and the plastic grip at the ends, from which the HDMI connectors protrude, is thicker than my other HDMI cables: this one is 1/2" from top to bottom instead of 3/8". I mention this because I'm using the cable to connect a laptop to a 5-year-old Samsung TV whose HDMI ports are flat against the rear of the TV, so that the cables lie flat against the TV where they plug into the HDMI ports. That is, the cables don't stick out perpendicular to the rear of the TV. In order for the TV to have that slim look that some people want, the manufacturer doesn't provide a lot of clearance between the TV's HDMI ports and the rear of the TV. There's plenty of room for my other HDMI cables (the ones whose plastic grips are 3/8" thick), but it's a very tight fit for the plastic grip at the end of this particular HDMI cable. I can imagine that TVs that are newer and more high-end than mine, and that are going for a thin, sleek look, might have even less clearance for the plastic grip of an HDMI cable, in which case you wouldn't be able to plug this cable in directly; you'd have to use an adapter.

This is the perfect quality cable I needed that has the right balance of thickness and flexibility.I needed a longer than standard 6-ft cable that could be easily transported for presentations made at multiple locations and this fit the need quite nicely. I had an older long cable that simply was too stiff and heavy to be portable. In fact, it was so heavy that it was unwieldy and often would not remain plugged in.This cable is surprisingly pliable and provides good shielding and high picture quality, but I have knocked my original five stars down a star because a second one of these cables I purchased broke at the connector within a few months of light use. Decent cable, but I'm hesitant to buy it again in the future.
They work like a HDMI cord and help with extenders, makes life simpler.

Connections are of good quality and I have had no issues with picture or sound quality. The only issue I have with this cable is that it is ridiculously thick and heavy. In some regards that is a good thing, but when it comes to routing, it is not easy to tuck, bend or hide. The cable that this one is replacing (due to a pet chewing it) was much thinner and I had it tucked between the carpet and base board. Not this beast. It also puts a lot of stress on HDMI ports due to the weight. I had to route it differently and zip tie it because I was worried about damaging ports. I suspect this length is rated to be installed inside of building walls. That would explain the extra thickness and shielding but I do not see it in the listing anywhere. The cable lengths below 15 feet appear to be "normal" cable in the pictures.TL;DRIf you want a sturdy HDMI cable that a semi could run over and not interrupt your movie this is for you. If you want something out of sight out of mind without running it behind drywall, maybe look elsewhere.

4 year without any major issues until now, not bad especially at the price we got it for! Purchased this HDMI cable back in June 2016. As of last year, we noticed it started giving out, screen would go black. We would adjust and it would work for a good while until the next time. Now, we have to rig it by placing something to hold the end connection in place so our screen doesn’t go black again. Also, Roku is popping up notices to check the HDMI cable too.I can’t find where to contact Amazon Basics regarding the limited lifetime warranty. Usually there is a “Contact Seller” button but not here. I’m sure I can find a 1-800 number somewhere but it’s not worth the hassle. I didn’t pay a lot for this cable back in 2016 and it served its purpose well while we had it. Not too concerned about getting a replacement. This cable is probable out-dated for today’s standards anyways.

reviewTitle: Gets the job done in a pinch
reviewDescription: I tend to lose a lot my cables especially my HDMI ones so this product is a pretty replacement when you're ina pinch. Gets the job done and with great value. Some downside though is that it is pretty short and might not work with your setup as well as it can be destroyed quite easily. I was shifting my table to the right a little bit and one of the legs landed on the product which totally destoyed one of the end. Lasted a good 6 months though!

reviewTitle: It is an HDMI cable. And it works as intended
reviewDescription: Like most electronics, it is a piece of conductive metal within a tube. Most HDMI cables should have reletively the same overall performance with picture quality. Amazon's provided cable works perfect as a cable to order quickly for anything that needs to be displayed on a monitor or tv screen.If you are looking for a cable, here's the one to pick. If you're looking for exceptional quality and durability in the cable, I recommend finding an alternative.

reviewTitle: Extra conductors/shielding/jacketing? It's like car battery jumper cable thickness.
reviewDescription: I like heavy duty cables but these are over the top. The size and weight puts a lot of stress at the connection point. It requires looping the cable and then cable tie the loop to the monitor mount. But, at the CPU, there's nothing to cable tie a strain-relief loop to.
Works well

reviewTitle: Basic HDMI cables as ordered works as expected
reviewDescription: The HDMI cables are as expected and perform as they are

I just replaced another brands (M.......e)  "Premium Certified" 6' HDMI cable with one of these.  It wasn't expensive but that cable failed after 6 months.  This Amazon cable has got things working perfectly again.  Already had one of these connecting another component to the same TV and it has worked fine.  I did, however, buy two of the 10' length cables for a second TV.  One did not work right out of the package.  The picture would drop out and TV would go to black screen.  The second one worked fine and is still in service.  One thing to nit-pick ... the cables appear to have gold plated connectors in the photo and the description seems to indicate the same.  Not that it matters, but the ones I received are just tin plated.  I just bought 2 more spares to have on hand.  Dismissing the one bad 10 footer I received, these cables handle all content that that we currently have available (up to 4K 24P) no problem.  Don't pay for the hype. They either work or they don't.  These work perfectly and are inexpensive.
nice heavy duty cable excellent buy for the money

reviewTitle: Uhh.. Only been using it for a few hours...
reviewDescription: Already, the first cable is occasionally flickering to black with no apparent cause. I have the second one still if it becomes too troublesome, but I'm not very hopeful about that one either... You really get what you pay for. I wouldn't recommend it as a primary cable, but for a second monitor for casual web browsing or something not so important, I'd 100% recommend it if you can tolerate the occasional flickering.

reviewTitle: 1 of 2 stopped working after about a month
reviewDescription: Got 2 in late June of 2020 — should've tested them both more thoroughly while I was still within the return window. As of sometime in August the signal cuts out every few minutes with one of the cables. Other one seems to work fine as of now. I'd recommend paying a little more for your HDMI cable.

I've been using this to connect my laptop to a dual monitor. It's worked fine for the first month or so, but it sometimes had difficulties connecting to the second display.This morning, it all but stopped showing anything on the second monitor. After I switched the HDMI cable to a different one, it went back to normal. It looks like the cable is not very reliable.

I purchased the 10ft version of this cable, and it the picture would show lines/turn black occasionally. At first, I decided to ignore the problems, but after a few days the screen was constantly flickering black. I've tested other HDMI cables and see no issues, so I've concluded that I just received a faulty cable.I've purchased a second cable in hopes that the issues are not present in it.Otherwise, I really like this cable, just wish it worked.

reviewTitle: Because the cable failed in less than 1 year,
reviewDescription: ecause it worked fine after installation. However about 6 months, I started to observe issue that the video image blacked out intermittently. I was not able to find the root cause, because the issue was intermittent, but recently I completely lost the image, and I identified that root cause is this HDMI cable. After I replaced the cable with another one, the image was recovered and didn't show any intermittent issue.
Sometimes I have to unplug, replug and play with the wire for it to work. My cables are less than 4 months

I bought a 2-pack of the 3 foot cables because it was the same price for both as for one. One of the cables worked fine, but the other didn't work with my DVD player or with my Roku ultra. I got pretty random errors, such as flickering between static and video, or it would work for a while before saying No Video. So if you are getting weird errors, try a different cable!

Received the product but this are not gold plated on the ends as described and shown in the picture.  Therefore I am not sure if I received the wrong order or it is misrepresented as described.  Hopefully it was just a mistake but regardless I had to return the item.

I thought this was an upgrade from Amazon's older HDMI cables but, I don't think so... This cable does not fully utilize the ARC (Audio Return Channel) capabilities; it will only transmit the power function and not any other control functions. Okay, this is only a basic cable but I have gotten other $5.00 cables which handle all ARC functions.Overall, this is a decent basic HDMI cable which delivers a clear HD picture. Plus, these cables appear well made.

reviewTitle: Grainy picture, not Dolby Vison compatable
reviewDescription: Meh, it’s an “ok” HDMI cable. If all you need is an inexpensive way to connect your device to your TV or monitor, then this will work. However, the picture quality is garbage. I had this connect to my AppleTV and the picture was really grainy. I guess I should have known better. I ended up ordering a different brand that is capable of 48Gbps and is Dolby Vison compatable, where as, this AmazonBasics HDMI cable is not.

Unfortunately I encountered a lot of issues with the 25ft 18Gbps cable. Sometimes it would work great, other times It wouldn't detect HDR compatibility, and often I would lose the signal completely. Don't buy the 25ft cable and expect reliable performance in 4K/60Hz/HDR.

This cable does its job, but barely.  Almost every time we turn on the TV, it pops up a message saying video quality has been changed for optimal viewing and we should replace cable with a better one for better quality.

reviewTitle: ****Is it really a 4K cable or rated at 4K
reviewDescription: There are many people saying in there reviews and answering questions that this is a 4K cable and there all the same anyways.  But I’m not sure I got a good price for a good 4K cable because nowhere on the box or cable does it say that it’s 4K or rated for 4K .So what did I really buy?  Nothing special , just another  hdmi cable.Very disappointed with this !  **I will always wonder if I’m getting the 4K quality .

reviewTitle: Beware if Using a Reciever and Dolby Vision with Apple TV
reviewDescription: As several other reviewers have pointed out, these cables don't work with with the fourth generation Apple TV via a receiver and 4k TV with Dolby Vision/HDR (LG OLED).  The sound is fine and they work well in other applications. However, after a few minutes of viewing, the picture usually would start to flash with a large block of white  pixels running across the bottom of the screen. We spent weeks of trying to solve the issue with tech support and various update and configuration changes, only to find that installing a Belkin cable solved the problem immediately.

reviewTitle: Seems to be a quality control issue with these cables. Very inconsistent in quality.
reviewDescription: First cable I had with Amazon basics lasted a good 3 years or so before it stopped receiving signal to the amplifier. I then noticed today, only after about a month; audio was transmitting, arc would work intermittently but there would be no video. (TV would show no signal for my HTPC or any device connected to the amp-- I could hear audio, but no video, so there is definitely a signal loss somewhere) I'm starting to think there is a issue with quality control with Amazon cables. While I have a lot of devices working fine with them, this is going to be a return and I'm switching brands this time around.

I thought these were ok, and then I compared their performance to another HDMI cord I had. When watching video, the picture is stilted and lags. The colors are over-saturated. I’m not typically picky about these things, but I bought these right before we moved and by the time I tried them, the return window had closed. Usually Amazon products don’t disappoint but these do. :(

Bought a two pack to use with my latest version of Apple TV and they both worked for about two weeks each and then stopped working. Bought the one apple suggested on their website and have not had any issues. I chose this one initially bc I’ve always had good luck with amazon products and this one said it supported the version of Apple TV I have. It’s a bummer it wasn’t as advertised and now I can’t get my money back bc the return window is closed.

reviewTitle: May not work on all TVs
reviewDescription: I purchased this to connect a new, very basic 19" Insignia TV to a cable box. Unbeknownst to me, some TVs require an HDMI/ethernet cable, so this standard HDMI cable did not work. This was also a surprise to the Xfinity installer, who happened to have the right cable on hand. Lesson learned: A standard HDMI cable does not necessarily work for all TVs. Amazon gave me a refund, but it would be nice if the description of this product noted that it may not work for all TVs.

reviewTitle: Had a problem with audio dropouts
reviewDescription: I had a problem with strange, random audio dropouts when using this HDMI with a Cisco CHS 435DHS Set Top Box / DVR (used with Verizon FIOS cable service) and an LG  Oled65b7a  65" OLED TV.  After a long investigation, the problem was fixed by replacing this cable with an HDMI cable provided by Verizon. It took several service calls and a Verizon $99 charge because the fault was in my cable. I've used Amazon basic cable in other places with good results but not with this equipment.

reviewTitle: AmazonBasics High-Speed HDMI Cable, 3 Feet 3 Set - Not Happy - One of The Three is Bad
reviewDescription: I have two issues with this Amazon Basics High-Speed HDMI Cable three pack.  One, I purchased under Amazon Prime, yet shipping was delayed.  Yeah, I know this is a minor issue but the second issue isn't.  One of the three cables is bad.  As soon as I plugged the cable in the display had pixelation.  I switched back to a known good cable and the issue was gone.  Tried a second time and the problem of pixelation returned.Normally I have good luck with Amazon Basic products, this is the first time exception. I'll contact Amazon, but I expect they will want me to return the all, two of the three are okay and being used.  Bummer.
Nice product
I love it

I bought this to hook a laptop up to the conference room TV at work.  The longer length allowed me to set the laptop on the conference room table even with the TV across the isle.  The picture quality was good and so was the sound.  Overall the cable appeared to be good quality upon visual inspection and I like the gold plated HDMI connectors on either end.The only reason I subtracted one star was because upon initially connecting the laptop to the TV there is a slight pop on the TV speakers and the picture shutters a bit.  Once it connects; however, everything is fine.  Not sure if it is the TV, the laptop or the cable, but the TV is a Samsung and the laptop a Dell, so I'm assuming it the cable.  However, for the price, I can't complain.

reviewTitle: Good cable with really thick insulation
reviewDescription: I ordered a few of these for long runs in a conference room. For my purpose-the far end connected to visitor's mobile devices-the thick insulation is a notable detriment.Presumably, you can look on the bright side and go, "Well, at least I won't bend it too tightly". That is true. But the insulation inhibits running the cable around normal bends, IMO. It also requires larger raceways to accommodate the cable or dual cables.
It's a perfect product at Amazon's Basics price. Good value and good connection.
The remote control cover does not snap in place so on my brand new Sony product I have to keep it in place with a rubber band, not a very good advertisement for a Sony product.
Nice heavy duty cable

reviewTitle: not better or worse than any of them
reviewDescription: Shouldn’t even cost this much, it should be free but if you are going to charge at least make the product cooler than the generics out there… it’s just a cord
The cable is well made, nice and thick, makes easy to connect my TV with laptop. Did the job in good price.

reviewTitle: Seems well built, but is bulkier than expected.
reviewDescription: This is a beefy cable!  I have only just recently hooked it up (I'm using it to connect a Mac Mini to a 40" 4K tv as a second monitor) but so far it is working as expected.Note that this is NOT simply a "standard" HDMI cable which happens to be 25' long, but it is also thicker than what I consider to be "normal" cables.  That's probably a good thing - I expect it should last and hold up to being connected/disconnected quite often - but the plug portion also seems to be larger than usual, meaning a bit of a tight fit next to other cables.  I'm also concerned about the weight of the cable itself putting stress on the outlet(s).It is also stiffer than "regular" cables, so if you need to wind/wrap the cable in a tight space, you might have an issue.

reviewTitle: Excellent quality but very thick and therefore not flexible enough for my needs.
reviewDescription: The cables are of very excellent quality; however, they are very "thick" and therefore are not flexible and are difficult if not impossible to uncoil.  I also had a problem with my laptop recognizing my monitor using them.  I cannot really explain why as when I used the previous shorter "Twisted " cable it recognized the monitor right away.  Perhaps they are made for a different reason.I want to make note here that I have never been disappointed in the Amazon Basics items I have purchased and they are much less costly.  I do not think that their line of products can be compared with generic items such as food products  No matter, you cannot go wrong.  I even purchase Amazon Basics batteries which last as long if not longer than any other brand, and are much more economical.

I'm sure it's here somewhere, just didn't look for this specific thing... Figured a cable is a cable... But this thing is thick!!  9.7mm according to my caliper... Too think for me to run under my carpet as planned... If that's not an issue, I'm sure it is a awesome cable with little signal loss, due to the gauge of the wires...

reviewTitle: They do the thing they're supposed to do
reviewDescription: no issues with the quality of the product or its output. i needed some of these for splitting a signal to multiple monitors and streaming, haven't had any issue with them at all.

reviewTitle: These cables should work with almost any setup
reviewDescription: I loved the fact that they are high speed cables for such a reasonable price.  Admittedly I have a more technical audio visual setup than most people.  My audio visual rack is about 70 feet away from the living room all run through HDMI baluns.  So this may be contributing to the sensitivity of my set up...I started getting sparkles and lines through the picture only when using the new Apple 4K TV not the cable box or blue ray player.  My old Apple TV didn't do this.  I tried several settings to get these picture defects to go away but the only thing that has worked is to reduce the output resolution down to 720p.  It looks as though the Amazon basic cables don't have the bandwidth for the new Apple 4K TV.
great for streaming
Seems like it works well enough, however I ordered the 6ft version and this is definitely not 6ft long. For reference, I’m 5’8” and this just barely reaches my head. Works fine though!
Good product alittle long.
It’s bit more expensive than the store brands like Best Buy, however only by a $1 or so. This gets the job done. Got the 3 ft one to connect my Apple TV to my mounted Samsung and so far so good.
Working as expected. Bought item as a replacement cord for our sound bar.
Satisfecho

reviewTitle: You get what you pay for
reviewDescription: It worked fine for about a year, but at this point it's unusable.  The cable now causes any output display to have a flicker/distortion at the top and bottom of the screen. I've tried three different displays (2 TVs. 1 monitor)  and two different outputs (computer/Switch), it's definitely the cable.  It's been sitting almost untouched for the entirety of its use, no bends or kinks in the cable.I have HDMI cables from ages ago that still hold up, I've never seen a cable fail like this without being abused in some way.  If you want something that's going to last, just pay a few bucks more for something you won't have to waste time testing and replacing.

I just bought a LG 65C8 OLED TV with a 10-bit Display, Model number: OLED65C8PUA...,  A week ago, And I have been on the hunt for a HDMI cable that will support, 4K Ultra HD, Dolby Vision®, Dolby Atmos, Advanced HDR, HDR10, HLG @ 18Gbps..After buying and trying a couple of different High Speed HDMI cable's here at Amazon, Including this one... Not one, Has worked without having Audio drop out's...My setup: LG 65C8 OLED connected to Denon X3200W via HDMI...Using the LG C8 in tv app's, Netflix, Amazon prime and VUDU....  All have the same Audio drop out's..I get perfect picture quality.... Just constant Audio drop out's....However, Watching my Time Warner Cable in DD 5.1 Audio, I have no issue's.... Strange, I know.....

reviewTitle: Poor quality leads to audio problems
reviewDescription: Bought this so we could watch amazon prime video shows on the tv.  We were getting by with our old 6 ft hdmi cord,  but decided the longer cord would be more convenient. Since using this cord, all of our video selections have audio issues.  The audio gets completely out of sync with the video picture.  Since it didn't happen with our old cord, it must be the quality of this cord.  Too late to return it - very disappointed.

reviewTitle: Thick cable but delicate cables internally
reviewDescription: This cable works for plugging in one time, but after a few times, I think the stress of the weight of the cable eventually made it stop working.  Doesn't matter which input or output device I'm plugging it to, it will not even detect a device was inserted.

reviewTitle: My 4K HDR Home Theater components don't like them.
reviewDescription: I'm usually a fan of most AmazonBasics items, but these cable are just junk. First bunch I ordered had several out of the box that didn't work at all, they replaced those and now most of all of them have quit working. I have a home theater setup, all 4K-HDR components..bluray, receiver, curved tv, and also xbox1 and ps4. When I upgraded the components in my system to 4K HDR capable, I bought these cables as an "upgrade". For some reason my Onkyo receiver and Samsung TV just don't like them. Samsung 4K bluray player doesn't either. They were intermittent at passing signal (for the ones that initially would work) until they failed. Drove me crazy trying to find the source of the problem since you never know upgrading all the components at once. Ended up putting my old HDMI cables back on and everything is working just fine.

reviewTitle: I just got it today bad news
reviewDescription: I just got it today. Excited to hook it up but with two in the box only one worked how very sad. My tv gave me a message that it wasn't connected to try turning the unit off and try again

Product description states this cable is made in Vietnam. It is not. The packaging clearly states made in China. I specifically bought this cable over others because it was supposedly NOT made in China….we will see how long it lasts…
There is a noticeable degradation of image and audio quality when using this cable.  I switched back to an excessively long cable because of how poorly this worked.

reviewTitle: Pay a few dollars more for 4k@60hz 4:4:4 compatible cables
reviewDescription: I originally really liked these cables but after more real world testing with 4K@60hz 4:4:4 they've come to disappoint. You might get away with using this if you have a single short run direct from device to TV. In my case, a PS4 Pro to LG OLED C8. It would give occasional partial snow on the screen that would flash. But, very occasional and worked most of the time. Once I ran through the receiver it became far less reliable and I had to switch cables entirely. My receiver does support pass-through for this format.Most people won't experience this unless you're using a PS4 Pro or PC that wants to send 4:4:4.

This cable caused me so much grief!!! I got a new soundbar and had issues getting 4k + HDR + Atmos working from my Xbox one S to make it to my TV. Ended up upgrading to a Xbox one x for the holidays to fix my issues and they were even worse! I had been bugging Samsung (soundbar) along with Microsoft (Xbox) for months! Finally swapped out this cable to a monoprice 8k cable and everything works now!!!This cable cannot handle too much thrown it's way! I agree, you don't need to spend a ton on an HDMI cable BUT you need one that can handle enough bandwidth!!
This cable was great at first about a month maybe not that long then I had to jiggle it to make the connection I'd did that for a week then it took a dump. I would not buy again

If you want to use this on a A/V setup that uses the latest tech, forget it. Tried using this on a setup with an Apple TV 4K, 4K OLED & Soundbar - Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos enabled, and it was unstable. Image had static, the tv would switch from Dolby Vision to lower bandwidth HDR randomly. The sound would occasionally make a popping sound. The fix: getting the $30 Dolby Vision certified cable from Belkin (48 Gbps). Not to mention this Amazon cable is super thick, fatter than coaxial cable!

reviewTitle: Worked for a while then stopped
reviewDescription: I bought this Amazon Basics HDMI cord about 5 months ago to connect monitor to my laptop for school work. Everything was going fine until a few days ago, when my monitor started having issues with connecting. I have determined my monitor is not the problem, but the cord. Now I'm stuck in COVID-19 quarantine without a working monitor to do work and school from home. My advice is to spend the extra and buy a nicer HDMI cord.

reviewTitle: Poor quality and one lasted only a week!!
reviewDescription: Had one cable just stop working after a week!! Very disappointing especially after I had cables hidden and fed through track just to have to pull it out a week later to install another new cable! Not sure why amazon would put their stamp on these??Update: I purchased the 10’ ones but just read some reviews and they say the 6’ or less work but greater than 6’ cables others are seeing the same issues I had for what that is worth to ya.

Cable length and material is nice.  However, I may have received a faulty cable.  On all devices I've used it on, the picture disconnects and reconnects if the cable or device moves just slightly.  It connects securely, but it is very touchy.

reviewTitle: Do not use for XBOX One. Cable does not fully seat in XBOX HDMI port receptacle.
reviewDescription: Not happy with these HDMI cables. The ends of the cables are SQUARED OFF right before the male HDMI connector. Many HDMI devices have their female HDMI ports recessed slightly. This squaring off of the cable ends blocks the cable from deeply seating in the HDMIi port of the device. An example of recessed HDMI ports is the XBOX One. I am constantly having to push the cable ends into the XBOX One HDMI ports to enable the video connection. The tips should be much flatter (tapered) as many other HDMI cables are. I cannot recommend due to this poor design flaw.

Used this to connect my projector.  There is a singe line that rolls up and down the top half of the screen.  This doesn't happen with the Chromecast or when i had the cable box closer with a shorter cable connecting the 2.  It is also a thick stiff cable.  Not very forgiving to bend. Otherwise the picture itself isn't bad

I designed computer circuits involving interconnections all my professional life. One project involved the redesign of of a marginal connector. I reviewed the design and construction of many different connectors and eventually submitted a redesign to correct the problems. This cable is a terrible example of an incompetent design. The connector is too short to support a cable not clamped to the housing. The bonding is nothing but pressure fit of plastic over metal, both plastic and metal being inferior. The only safe way to use this is to have the whole cable clamped in  a way to prevent ANY!!!!!! stress on it from handling the cable or moving the connected equipment.

reviewTitle: This cable is unnecessarily huge! it's so fat
reviewDescription: This cable is unnecessarily huge! it's so fat.  Shielding is important for analog signals but come on man this is a pretty standard digital signal and I don't think 15ft is very far to worry too much. I guess you can almost see it from the picture, but it seems a heck of a lot bigger in person.  geesh.  The Amazon 6ft was really nice and I was hoping it would be the same but it's not. One nice thing is that it is a nice flexible material like the 6th one.

reviewTitle: those cables would not allow the XBOX to work in 4K
reviewDescription: ed flawlessly (no artifacts, flickering or other issues), the other two did not work as well. I tried Twisted Veins HDMI cables as well and had similar issues. I finally picked up Monoprice cables and haven't had any problems. Most people have good luck with these cables in shorter lengths (6ft or less), however at 10ft or longer I recommend looking for something else if you are using these on a 4K display. The two issues I saw with t

reviewTitle: Does not work between Samsung Blu-Ray and Samsung Soundbar with Samsung TV (!)
reviewDescription: I installed this cable -- well, a couple of them, in fact, between my Samsung Smart TV and several items back in 2017.  My Blu-Ray player and Soundbar are also Samsung devices.  Zero compatibility question between them.  Well, the Blu-Ray is connected to the Soundbar, and the Soundbar is connected to the TV.  Boring by-the-book setup.  Scads of problems with the TV deciding it couldn't figure out what the Soundbar was, intermittently, if you turned up the Blu-Ray player.  To get it all working again was a complex exercise in resetting the TV via unplug or sparsely-documented reset sequence, blah blah blah.I blamed the Blu-Ray.  Kind of an edge device in the age of streaming, whatever.  Until 2022.In 2022, things got weirder and wouldn't behave in bigger terms.  HDCP errors, sound but no video, plus the original set of issues if trying to use the Blu-Ray player.  On a hunch, I decided to swap out this Amazon cable, replacing it with a not-Amazon one that had been more recently produced (and, interestingly, thicker).All those problems that had been in and out starting with the original install went buh-bye.  Permanently.Note again that I have more than one of this Amazon cable.  There was one going from the Blu-Ray to the Soundbar, and one going from the Soundbar to the TV.  Apparently the one going to the Blu-Ray is incompatible with whatever is going on in all these communications, to the point of the Blu-Ray-Soundbar cable keeping the TV -- connected by ANOTHER of the same Amazon cable -- from figuring out how to talk to the Soundbar at all.  Loud, clear, comm issues, which suggests a standards compliance issue.Or at least a standards compliance issue that affects things that talk to Samsung Blu-Ray players and/or Soundbars.  Beats me.I want to give this cable more stars but with that kind of history, I simply can't.  Unfortunate, because it seemed like a good buy.

reviewTitle: What good is great picture quality when the cable goes kaput?
reviewDescription: Sure it's cheap. Sure we got over a year's worth of usage out of it. But the long and the short of it is that it FAILED COMPLETELY, right in the middle of an important work meeting. In the middle of a presentation. Black Screen of Death. A most inconvenient and embarrassing episode. Lots of yelling. A curse word or two...or a couple of dozen. Belatedly I had to scavenge the HDMI cable off of my Xbox in order to get my wife's work computer back to operational order. Good thing I happened to be home, else who knows what I might've come home to.I suppose it could happen to any cable. But it DIDN'T. It happened to THIS one. I guess this unit was one of the 2 percenters (represented by the "one star" crowd reviling this product here on Amazon). So much for glorification of the "Basics". 'Miffed' doesn't even begin to describe the feeling. 'Torqued' however begins to...That said, I recently bought a 6 foot Amazon Basics HDMI cable...for the second time. Originally I had intended on using this new 6 footer for another device that I've got coming. The first 6 foot cable was purchased around the SAME TIME as this 3 footer that failed. So here's hoping that it continues to run on my second Xbox One, as this new one returns my first Xbox One back into service. And I now must decide whether I want to chance going cheap again and using yet ANOTHER Amazon Basics HDMI cable for this new inbound computer, or just suck it up and buy a more expensive 'name brand' cable and hope that its quality is better. I mean only 2% of absolute negativity isn't a bad ratio. Better than even Pfizer's COVID vaccine's success rate. Odds are heavily in my favor that such a calamitous failure won't happen a second time, right?Except when and if it does. Which NOW I can't get out of my mind. It's just like all of those cheap, money-sucking USB cables that are endlessly sold here on the website and fail miserably months if not weeks on.Thanks Amazon.

I bought this cable about 18mo ago to work with my Channel Master DVR+. I cut the cord years ago and liked the CM7500+ OTA DVR so much I went back for a 2nd, but alas, they didn't make them anymore. Finally found a used one on eBay; bought it. Bought this new cable to interface it with my new Yamaha Receiver. Live TV was perfect, but DVR playback was plagued with intermittent drop-outs of AUDIO ONLY. I assumed it was the used eBay Channel Master CM7500+ OTA DVR for quite sometime since is was only audio and only playback; never live TV. . I recently had spare time on my hands recovering from surgery and started more in depth troubleshooting. Reseated the HDMI cable several times on BOTH ends (cause is was driving me crazy with all of the TV I had to watch during recovery); no change at all. Noticed the DVR+ had a mini optical audio out port. Bought a new fiber optic cable and replacement HDMI cable as well since I was jumping in. Verdict: NO MORE Audio dropouts regardless of whether I used the new fiber-optic OR the new HDMI cable. THIS cable was ONLY 3' long; what the hell? The new cable is 3x-4x the cost of THIS one and designed to work with 8k signals - which this is not. But the bottom line is that these audio drop-outs were driving me nuts, and I lived with it waaaaay waaaaay tooo long. I find it curious that the video was not an issue (Intermittent audio loss was regardless of dolby digital [any flavor] or two channel stereo). AMAZING how nice it is when things suddenly work the way they're supposed to.

I'm big into the latest and greatest technology but I don't always understand it. I'll tell you in my laymen's terms that these are garbage. I researched and figured we were saving money and that these were the latest and greatest. We just bought a 4K OLED tv and realized our current cables weren't high speed so I needed new ones. I bought these and hooked them up. I think we've had them a month and we were playing with our son on the PS4 and accused him of sitting on the tv remote because in the middle of a game the screen just went blank and acted like nothing was hooked up to the HDMI. This happened 3 more times in the same day and finally my husband switched out the HDMI cable after we realized no one was sitting on the remote. Obviously these are basically worthless if they only work for month. Getting returned and not sure what to buy now because I hate having to research things. I was really hopeful with the great price and reviews though.Update: I completely forgot to return these hunks of trash and they got shoved into a box of cables. Totally forgot about them. Fast forward a few years and we got a new Apple TV 4K. Hooked it all up and it worked fine for one day. Second day the screen flickered once in a while. Then it got more and more steady. VERY annoying, thought maybe it was the Apple TV, troubleshooted, still had the issue. After about 20 minutes the screen started straight up flickering black and gray and there was no picture at all. Reset everything, unplugged and replugged in everything and it was fine. 20 minutes later same crap again. Figured maybe it was the HDMI cable and swapped it out for a different brand. NO issues. Came on here to review and saw that I already had. I’ve had these just sitting in a box for like 4 years. They are complete garbage. I deeply regret not returning them. No idea why I didn’t.

reviewTitle: vendor will not accept a return..
reviewDescription: vendor bad policy, they will not accept a return. They only offer trouble shooting ttips. Thier tips are wrothless, I needed a display port to hdmi, there is no troubleshooting that will fix that.

reviewTitle: Broke within a few months of buying!
reviewDescription: Broke within a few months and no longer works for my monitor computer connection. Very frustrated and would like a replacement.

reviewTitle: 10 Feet cable does not work with the PS4 Pro or the Xbox one S
reviewDescription: I ordered the 10 Feet cable and was sorely disappointed with the quality of the cable, its not like the 3 and 6 feet Amazon Basic cables. Right off the bat the HDMI connectors are flimsy and very short so there is a lot of pressure of the connectors if you connect them at right angles. Second issue and a deal breaker for me is that although it says this is the latest standard which I assumed is HDMI 2.0a this cable does not work with the PS4 pro and the Xbox one S. Both my gaming systems would not display HDR, whenever I tried to view something with HDR my TV would lose signal(I have the LG Oled E6 65inch). My PS4 pro would not even display anything after powering up with this cable, my Xbox one S would display at 4K but when playing HDR my TV would lose signal.On a side note if you do have a PS4 pro and a LG Oled E6 65inch TV and you have problems getting HDR to work or you do not get a signal when you power on your PS4 pro system try this it worked for me:1. Connect the PS4 pro with the HDMI cable which came with it to HDMI 1 on your TV ( I have 4 HDMI inputs and for some reason PS4 Pro only worked on HDMI 1 for me.2. Make sure deep color is enabled for HDMI 1 ( I enabled it for all my HDMI inputs)For now avoid this cable and just use the cable that came with your gaming consoles, I will be returning this cable and trying out the media bridge cables. Will update my results.

reviewTitle: Cannot stream 4K video from Fubo or other DRM-protected sources. NOT compatabile with HDCP 2.2!!
reviewDescription: There are 2 Q&A answers that say this cable is HDCP 2.2 Compatible. This is not true! Look for the tiny, obscure link to the product manual PDF. The cover page reveals this cable is built to the HDMI 1.4 standard, which does not support streaming 4K content from DRM-protected sources like FUBO sports broadcasts.Also, if you look closely at the product description, it shows this was originally manufactured in 2015. That means it's effectively obsolete, as many streaming services are increasingly mandating HDCP 2.2 functionality, and for that you need an updated cable, which this is NOT.Amazon Basics shouldn't really be selling this obsolete cable here in 2024.

reviewTitle: If you need a 10 ft cable for 4k, don't buy this one.
reviewDescription: This is a review for the 10 ft cable.  Although they list this as the latest standard, let me save you the hassle.  This will not do 4k @ 60 Hz. I've seen the Amazon cheerleader with the screenshots saying this cable works with 4k and HDR. My cable did not.  I should've taken some screenshots with my Xbox one X error list (but I didn't).  I freaked out when I hooked this up to my Xbox one X and the system reported it would not do full 4k but only upscale to 4k for games. I added a compatibility option which then said it would do 4k and HDR for movies, but would still not do games in Native 4k with HDR. First problem was my Sony TV was not set to Enhanced HDMI mode.  When I corrected that, the screen had red snow all over the background.  I freaked out thinking my Xbox was broken or my TV was not working properly.  After a couple hours of troubleshooting, I traced it down to the new "latest standard" HDMI cable I bought from Amazon.  I also noticed that other people have run into the same issue specifically with the 10 ft cable (see the Q&A section). Amazon refunded my money without question and I was able to purchase a functional cable from another seller on Amazon.  It works great and my Xbox now has no issues with all of the 4k display options.  If you need a 10 ft cable, buy this https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01CRA11IU/ref=cm_sw_r_em_apa_Q0LeAb0J3AYQWIt's a few bucks more, but it works.

reviewTitle: Don't Believe These Can Handle HDR
reviewDescription: Purchased these in December of 2016. Wanted to like these cables. I don't think they can handle HDR. Just picked up a 75 inch Samsung UN75MU800DFXZA (one of the top rated 75 inch TV's according to CNET and Consumer Reports) from Costco and had this weird distorted high lighting / shine effect on faces in movie mode (see attached pictures) and in scenes where the background was blurry it would also create this same strange effect. I exchanged my TV for another one to make sure it wasn't the TV (TV also came with a blemish and the google play credit had already been redeemed which made me question whether or not my TV was new) and the same effect persisted in my replacement TV. It happened all throughout the 4K/HDR hard disc version of Wonder Woman being played through an Xbox One S to where we had to change out of movie mode (which uses darker colors,etc). I decided to try some rocketfish cables from Best Buy since they were on sale and considered "certified". The issue went away immediately in Wonder Woman, color and contrast was vivid and normal.  I tried a Netflix show through a Roku Ultra and the effect was partially there but not as bad, it then went away and I could not replicate again which makes be think its a bandwidth issue. I changed my Netflix settings to display the highest resolution picture and haven't noticed the issue since with the new rocketfish cables from best buy.  The biggest difference was in Wonder Woman disk, playing through an Xbox One S, issue was completely gone and this movie was not being streamed.

I see some conflicting reviews on this topic as far as ARC working or not, but not everyone is identifying the length of the cable. For me, the 25' cable did not offer full ARC functionality. I was increasing the distance between a TCL Smart TV and a pretty high end Dolby decoder, which had no issues with a 15' Amazon Basics cable between the same 2 devices. With the 25' cable the TV did see the Dolby during CEC device search, but identified the Dolby's HDMI port as non-ARC, which I know is incorrect because it functions with the shorter cable. Is cable length a factor or is it simply a cable defect? I can't say. I also can't discount the possibility that the TCL is somehow contributing too - it's not a high ent unit.
Unfortunately HDMI cable continues to short upon first use. Monitor signal does not stay connected and continues to go in and out every few minutes. Would. It recommend

These were purchased almost two years ago to make sure everything would be future proof.  I have a Samsung UN65JS8500 and Denon AVR-S900W which both support HDMI 2.0, HDCP 2.2, 4k 60Hz in 4:4:4.These are the only type of cables I use and so far:- My PS4 Pro can't detect HDR.- My Samsumg UBD-K8500 can't detect HDR and the picture flickers in and out while the sound keeps playing.- My Roku Ultra can't do 4k 60HZ 4:4:4 but will do 4k 30Hz 4:4:4.- My PC can only connect at 4k 60Hz 4:2:2.Every 4k device I have was purchased to use all the features of my tv and I'm pretty sure these cables are why they don't.I wish I had known this was one of Amazon's own product lines that doesn't live up to its claim.

reviewTitle: Bad Experience and Bad HDMI Cable
reviewDescription: Literally the first day that I got it, it didn’t work. Mind you, I opened it right out of the bag and connected my ps4 to my t.v. Right away, the picture isn’t clear, there is static, and the sound isn’t working all the way. So, I went to get a replacement, but out of the blue, the HDMI Cable starts working perfectly, so I canceled the replacement. Now, it’s back to how it was, not working, and now I can’t get the replacement without returning the item. I have to return the item, with a refund. This whole HDMI Cable just caused such a hassle all night long. I have never had to experience this ever when ordering from Amazon, and I have ordered an HDMI Cable from here before. Just a bad experience overall.

I purchased this two-pack of HDMI cables to connect my laptop to my television.  One to use, and one as a spare.  After about 10 months of using the first cable, it suddenly stopped working.  Tested it across other devices and televisions - dead.  BUT - I had my spare, so no problem.  Until 3 months later, and now that one works 50% of the time.  Plugging and unplugging plays the "will-it-work" lottery, but I don't have high hopes for a long future.I don't know why they don't work, but also know that they haven't been asked to do much.  Disappointed, and would not purchase these again.  It makes me reconsider choosign Amazon brand electronics in the future.

I bought this and it worked great on my tv and ps4 for a couple of days. Yesterday I was going to play ps4 and the signal wouldn’t show on my tv. I took the hdmi cable out of the ps4 and hooked it up with my laptop and tv and was not able to see anything either. I went and bought a new one at Walmart and it worked on my laptop, but not the ps4. I looked more closely with a flashlight and my ps4 HDMI port had a small thin stick stuck to it. I looked at the bad HDMI cable and it had a small piece break off, the one inside my ps4 HDMI port. So now, I can’t play my ps4 because of this cheap piece of garbage...

After 10 months one screen started goring off (no signal) intermittently the after a week it went off permanently. One month later the second Display to HDMI cable started displaying the same symptoms. I tried them on different monitors and different computers but still receiving 'no signal'. Now, my computer can see there is a monitor connected (even the brand) but the monitors receives no image. The cables are..well were in a permanent position, never moved for the entire year. The issue seems to be in the circuitry in the cable rather than a loose connection. The cable started 'blacking out' then went dark eventually.So if you want a quick fix or for a one-off job buy them but if you want to plug-in and forget it look elsewhere.

This is probably the most disappointed I've been in an Amazon product.  I've bought 11 of these cables, and they were fine for 4K60 HDR 10.  But I've had trouble with dolby HDR, specifically with an Apple TV 4K.  I'd also been unable to enable HDR on a Windows 10 htpc.  I spent hours troubleshooting over the months, when the only problem was these cables.  With the Apple TV I'd get random black screens and a note once, stating that my cable or TV could not support the resolution.On an Audio Video forum, I read about other people's problems similar to mine, and ended up buying monoprice premium cables.  Problem solved.  I dont know if this is a quality control issue, because these cables per their specs, should have no problems with any 4K resolution.
This was much larger than was advertised. It is much to large for what I need it for. I guess that I'll give it away. I'm never ordering from these people again.

I bought this bag for volleyball weekends for my children. I really liked the size of the bag and the colore(grey/aqua blue) I used it maybe 3 times and the front pocket seam started to fray and rip. I can no longer put important items in that compartment bc they will fall out. I was very disappointed by the quality.

reviewTitle: This cable will not support a 4K signal!  It didn't for me.
reviewDescription: I am using this between a projector and a 4K Apple TV.  This cable worked okay when connected to a Nintendo Switch (720p) or to a BlueRay player (1080p); however when connected to the Apple TV, the projector displays "No Signal" or "Not Supported."I spent 30-60 minutes trying to figure out why the Apple TV wouldn't come up.  I even tried reversing the cable as I remember some longer HDMI cables are unidirectional - same results.  You would think the Apple TV would fall back to 1080p if it couldn't negotiate a 4K signal (but it didn't, not with this cable anyways).  This was very frustrating.  If I use a different cable between my 4K Apple TV and projector, it works fine.Given others' reviews, where it seems to work for many but fail for a percentage of customers, it seems that they don't test these cables when they are manufactured.  I presume that they have a failure rate that simply gets passed on to the customers and we were one of the unlucky ones.  Thanks for ruining our much-anticipated family movie night.  We'll have to pay $$$'s to a local box store for a long cable or wait a couple of days on a new cable to arrive.My Experience:  This is a cheap cable.  It will not support a 4K signal.Lesson Learned:  If you want a quality signal, purchase a quality cable.

I am not happy. I bought this for my xbox one s and the picture was shaky and looked like a computer screen when you film it with a phone (if you know what i mean). I hated it but I thought I could live with it. So I powered thru, until I had only been watching youtube the first 2 days and decided I wanted to play a game and I clicked on minecraft. Literally anytime I tried to watch something (netflix, disney +, etc) that wasnt a youtube video, the screen would go, picture, black, picture, black, picture, black. And it would not stop until I unplugged the power.I thought my xbox broke, this has never happened before I plugged this hdmi cord in.So I plugged in my hdmi cord I bought from walmart in the livingroom and boom it was fine. No flashing on and off, no shaky gross picture.I usually love every product from amazon but this one was worthless for me. Not worth the chance. Go to walmart.

reviewTitle: does NOT support HDCP - read on
reviewDescription: Bottom Line,  These cables do not support HDCP so you will NOT get the dialogue track, only the sound track associated with the video stream, making for some very interesting streaming of movies... LOL.I recently ordered, installed new HDMI cables to support 4K in my home theater system.  The thing about 4K is that all the devices and cables from content provider to display must be 4K compatible or the digital content drops to the least common denominator in the path.My wife and I thought we were watching a very avant-garde episode of FOREVER (Amazon Prime) through our Roku, where we could hear the music soundtrack but the character's dialogue was silent (like a silent film).  We thought the producers wanted us to figure out we needed to watch this episode with sub-titles and CC to get the true expression of the characters and feeling of the episode and to watch it as someone who was hearing unsound would watch it.  I have to say, it was quite a pleasant  and awesome experience not to mention the episode fit right into watching it this way.  But when we watched a different series, the same technical flaw occurred, which led me to look at the cabling.  I had to swap out this new cable from my Roku to receiver to get back the dialogue. These cables do not support HDCP.

reviewTitle: It's not the monitor or the drivers on Windows 10....its the low quality cable
reviewDescription: I really dont ever give one star feedback on an item and Amazon basics products have been really great for me in all other circumstances. This HDMI cable might work for some electronics that dont require superior quality cable for HD or 4K monitors and TVs. I bought this one because it was shown as "frequently purchase with" add on for an HD monitor I bought to use with my HP laptop as a second screen. It worked for two days and stopped after that. I wish I could have known it was the brand new cable right away...but I looked at reviews on the monitor and saw people blaming the problem on the cheap monitor from Acer....or people thought it wasnt compatible with windows 10. All you get is a message that your computer won't detect the monitor. I tried windows updates...rolling back display drivers, updating drivers, flushing bios,  HP tech help, Acer Tech help....in the end after trying everything else I was about to throw the monitor away and get an HP monitor...expecting that since all my other devices were HP...it would work. Then as I was about to order it I was also going to get the HP HDMI cable. I decided to try just the new cable first. Two days later I got the cable...plugged it in....Bob's your uncle...it worked just fine! In fact the picture quality was even better than before.

reviewTitle: Didn't Work On a Headless Client Windows 7 Box
reviewDescription: I purchased this cable primarily to use during a Windows 10 pro upgrade on a Windows 7 Pro Box.  It's a headless client and in day to day ops, I just RDP to it.  RDP will present some issues during the upgrade if a monitor isn't directly attached and that was my goal in getting this cable.  I tried for an hour on a known good HDMI port on my 1080 TV.  Nada.  It wouldn't pick up that anything was connected.  Figuring it might be my Windows 7 box, I updated drivers, etc. to no avail.  I then figured let me use a known good HDMI cable from my Roku, ran that to another working TV and expected it not to work as I thought the problem was my Windows 7 box but bam, instant success.  I know a lot of people have had good luck with this cable but I got a lemon.  By the way, I have purchased many great HDMI Amazon Basic cables over the years with much luck but my hope here was to get the 25 footer and then leave it run in case I ever needed to boot off USB, etc. and use my primary monitor.  Oh well.  I'm skeptical to try another after this.  Very thick and heavy cable, too, by the way.

reviewTitle: I cannot figure out if this is HDCP compliant
reviewDescription: I am now getting a HDCP error when using my phone and this cable. I reread the specs and can’t determine if this meets the HDCP standards which is frustrate I didn’t even know they existed before I received error. I hope Amazon would sell cables that don’t meet these requirements

I got mildly electrocuted by one of these coming out of my Onkyo. I’ve never ever had that happen with any other HDMI cable and earnestly was surprised by it. I learned my lesson though: don’t buy cheap HDMI cables. Unless you want to get electrocuted.

This cable resulted in red dots all over my 4K display and had to be replaced. Worked well with 1080p. Don't know if I got unlucky or if other reviewers haven't used this for 4K signals, but I'd avoid this one going forward.

Great in the beginning, but then my picture started breaking up as I was booting into Windows.  Replaced with a cable that has 2-year guarantee, and was $5 more.  Usually, Amazon Basics works out for me, but not this time.

reviewTitle: Do not buy this cable, only one year warranty not lifetime
reviewDescription: I thought Amazon basics cables were good quality at a low price. Turns out it's poor quality at a low price. I also thought Amazon basics cables were under a limited lifetime warranty, but this product is only under a one year warranty. My cable ended up lasting less than 3 years, for a cable to fail in less than 3 years it has to be poorly made. And Amazon shows how little confidence they have in it with only a one year warranty.Like some of the other negative reviews mentioned here, my tv started flickering on and off. I went crazy trying to find out what the problem was with my receiver, my tv, and my pc. I was changing settings and plugging and unpugging a bunch of stuff, a lot of time was wasted. Then I thought unlikely as it is, maybe I can try changing the HDMI cable. And instantly the problem was fixed, it was this poorly made cable that was causing the problems. DO NOT BUY IT, there are many affordable options out there that are better and they don't screw you with a one year warranty.

The HDMI cable works fine, but it's absurdly thick. I'd guess twice as thick as most regular HDMI cables. With all that girth it acts like a spring, so if you plug it into a small device (IoT/Raspberry Pi), it wants to uncoil and flip the device. The plastic around the plug is also really thick, so it doesn't easily fit into screens with little clearance room. The video quality is good at 1920x1200. I haven't tested it at higher resolutions.

reviewTitle: Does not work for 1440p144hz - Cable might be too long
reviewDescription: Warning: Does not work at 2560x1440p 144hz displays.I tried this 10ft HDMI cable with my GTX 1080 and the ASUS MG278Q 1440p144hz monitor that has a HDMI 2.0 input.When connected, the display would not turn on unless I set the resolution/fps to 1440p 120hz. At 1440p120, the image came up on the display and there were no issues.Using the same cable, but 6ft version, I could run the display at 1440p144hz.This leads be to believe that the issue is with the cable length, even though 10ft is not very long. Maybe bad materials are used?

reviewTitle: Thicc cable but gets the job done
reviewDescription: To start off, the cable works great. Got solid picture quality and was plenty long enough (25ft) but the cable is stupid thick. I have a shorter version of this cable and it’s much, much thinner. I expected the 25ft cable to be thicker but it is almost an inch thick. I had planned on tucking this cable away but since it’s so thick and stiff it’s hard to tuck it away or keep it from bundling back up.Tl;dr - Great cable if you don’t mind it being super thicc

The hardware itself is great. Chrome OS on the other hand is mostly terrible... My biggest complaint is the file system because it cannot handle more than 50 folders or 1000 files in a given directory before it crashes. It reminds me of how clunky drive.google.com is when dealing with a directory with 300+ folders. Try moving a file to your desired folder and you will know what I mean.This might be great for a casual user or as an HTPC but I did not spend enough time with it to test this.

reviewTitle: It works very well, but be prepared:  it's VERY thick and heavy duty.  Not quite what I expected with an HDMI cable.
reviewDescription: Though it works as it should, it is VERY thick and heavy.  I didn't expect it to be so heavy duty.  My original plan was using this with my laptop to stream movies onto my TV, and though I can do this and it works well, the cable is very thick and heavy.  Much thicker than a standard HDMI cable.  About the same thickness as an orange extension cord.  Yes...that thick.  It's definitely made to last, that's for sure.As for its performance, it works as it should.  No artifacts.
Length and quality are PERFECTcord is VERY STIFF and difficult to bend at close to 90 degree angle....straight runs are fine
seems to work on my older model tv so its ok

Worked well for a bit but after around 1.5 years of use the picture on my second monitor would start flashing while using the cable. The issue went away when using a different cable so I guess it just has a two year lifespan

Purchased these hefty cables after being loaned another pair from my neighbor.  His cables were also excellent quality from Amazon's own brand.  When mine arrived, the first thing I noticed is the thickness of the cable.  His cables were half the diameter as the ones I ordered.  Not sure why so thick.  The quality is there and overall they are well made.I have decided to keep the cable as they work the same.  Recommended
Product was as described but the cords was very thick and hard to maneuver. Had to really bend the cord to get it to plug into the TV.

reviewTitle: Decent HDMI cables but not premium certified
reviewDescription: Not the best but not the worst.  It will work for most applications and some will work for 4K 60Hz but some won't (which is why some of the reviews here seem to contradict each other).  The problem is that HDMI standards are kind of sketchy these days.  The current "high speed" HDMI spec requires 10.2 Gbps testing but companies are allowed to sort of cheat and extrapolate to say it should work for 18 Gbps.  The only way to know if a cable has actually been tested for 18 Gbps is if the cable is premium certified, which these aren't.  Monoprice sells premium certified cables for about the same price as these and blue jeans cables sells higher quality premium certified cables at reasonable prices.  I'd recommend BJC if you want to make sure you don't have issues between your high end 4K equipment or Monoprice if you want the lowest cost premium certified cables.

reviewTitle: Should have bought it years ago
reviewDescription: Dislikes: The Velcro securing straps fell apart from sun damage in a few months. A real dumb design.Not much to say outer than it does the job and even protects the wipers from sun damage. What I would like is the ability for the side pieces had screen panel over the widows in order to have more ventilation. I might try that myself. I would also like a small clear panel in the front so peek out to the front.

The cable is very thick. It is difficult to bend and use in areas that have limited space for wires. It will also take up twice the space in grommets or pass throughs.With that said, the cable does work well.

Product is rated CL3, with 32AWG which is under the standard recommended gauge for wires of this length. The wire is noticeably thinner than my other HDMI cables rated 28/30.Plugs in and works just fine, but will be returning as the wire is uncomfortably thin for my use. If you aren't going to be twisting the wire a lot you might be okay, but YMMV.

Three stars due purely to inconsistency in quality. Ordered one pair, and one of the cables works (and the other doesn’t) when hooked up to sources using HDR10. Both cables work fine if hooked up to sources not requiring this much bandwidth. Still super cheap if you don’t mind the potential waste of some being to full spec and some not. The cable that works looks and sounds great. No discernible video or audio issues, though it may take longer to complete initial HDCP handshake than my previous cables (I think... could be mis-remembering and I’m not going to check) even though it will complete the handshake.I will be trying a different brand for my next purchase as I am looking for cables that work with HDR10 sources and I do mind the waste.
Would buy again
Good backup, but found there is a quality loss from my regular HDMI cable

reviewTitle: Thick heavy and stiff. Only buy if you plan to plug this cord in and then never move it again.
reviewDescription: I bought this cord to connect my computer to the TV . It is about as thick as my pinky finger and very stiff making it awkward to fit behind the tv when not in use and making it hard to position the computer without the cord pushing the computer around and sometimes putting tension on the hdmi port which causes connection issues as well as not being great for the port long term. the coiled up cord is also about as heavy as my laptop and takes up as much room in a bag, so not great for portability. it is long and seems to work fine other than the connection issues from it being so stiff and hard to position correctly.

I’ve never heard of one of these cords not fitting well but it just seems loose and it always needs to be adjusted. I don’t know if I got a bad one or if this model is not made right but I recommend trying something else

reviewTitle: 3x as thick as any HDMI cable I've used
reviewDescription: Cable seems to work well and is well built. Two issues that bother me is 1) cable thickness and 2) connector she'll size.1) Could be good or bad depending on your needs, but I needed to run this through a narrow channel. The cable is 3x as thick as the one I'm replacing which made things much more difficult.2) I feel like the connector casing is bulkier also. Again, probably good for durability, but I could see it getting in the way of ports, as it is currently pressed up all the way against where I've plugged it it. Works fine so far, but I could see it possibly coming loose if disturbed

reviewTitle: Good for a year or so
reviewDescription: Worked well for a short time but like most things made today is cheaply made inside and I find that it shorts occasionally causing me to mess with the plug-in part. Maybe I just got one that was made by a lazy worker? It happens... maybe a design flaw though. All in all I don't think that throwing more money at another one would necessarily mean that it is made any better as most companies today want to use the cheapest materials put together by the most inexpensive labor that they can possibly find and it shows.

I bought a new 4K HDTV in November 2015 and bought new AmazonBasics High-Speed HDMI cables for it.  While buying another 4k TV this month  I noticed that a new 2.0 standard for HDMI cables was recommended.  I checked my 2015 cables and no where on the cable do they say 2.0.
