As of May 9th, 2019, the bullet points list the cable as supporting 18Gbps.  Further down, the manufacturer only claims 10.2Gbps.  The packaging and cable markings provide no clue about the actual supported speed.  According to wikipedia (and elsewhere), hdmi cables labeled as "high-speed" support 10.2Gbps, and hdmi cables labeled as "premium high-speed" support 18Gbps.After purchasing, my conclusion was that these are only guaranteed to support 10.2Gbps (4K at 30Hz) and will NOT guarantee 18Gbps (4K at 60 Hz) which is common in hardware nowadays.  The bullet points are false and misleading.  18Gbps may work at smaller lengths but is NOT guaranteed.

reviewTitle: There is no need to buy more expensive HDMI cables
reviewDescription: Please do not waste your hard earned money on overpriced HDMI cables in the name of picture or sound improvements. I currently am using these AmazonBasics High-Speed HDMI cables to connect our Yamaha v379 AV receiver to other HDMI enabled devices that link back to our 4K Samsung Smart TV and these have performed flawlessly.HDMI cables come in four types: Standard-speed --> Standard-speed with Ethernet --> High-speed --> High-speed with Ethernet. Since High-speed cables are so cheap (e.g these AmazonBasics cables), there really isn't any point of getting Standard-speed anymore. On the other hand, as most HDMI devices today can't receive Ethernet over HDMI, High-speed HDMI cables are really all you need.** Some numbers **Standard-speed HDMI cables are rated up to 1080i ("i" stands for interlaced). In order for a HDMI cable to have a "High-speed" moniker, it must be capable of showing resolutions up to 4K --> 3840 x 2160 at 30fps (or 4,096 x 2160 at 24fps). And as the highest resolution any 4K TV currently on the market can produce is 3840 x 2160 at 30fps, even if you found a $100 cable at your local BestBuy that claims it can transmit much more than that, it doesn't matter as you are limited by your source (i.e your cable box, Xbox, PS4 e.t.c) and your TV's hardware capabilities.Also HDMI cables can either produce an image/sound or nothing at all. There is NO in between. Therefore, a HDMI cable will either work or won't work (it may show a flashing image but this means it's a bad cable). But a more expensive HDMI cable will NOT show darker blacks and sharper colors than a less expensive HDMI cable. You either get 100% of the signal or no signal at all. Now if you intend on running your HDMI cable for more than 50ft, then you might want to invest in a HDMI cable that has "active" chips that help maintain the signal quality over a longer distance (but does NOT make the image/sound any better than the source).** What about HDMI 1.4 or 2.0 or HDCP 2.2? **This is another common misconception due to manufacturer marketing. HDMI 1.4, 2.0 and HDCP 2.2 are all hardware changes that do NOT require a cable change! Although there is a difference between them (you can google that yourself), there is no such thing as a HDMI 1.4 or 2.0 or HDCP 2.2 cable! The version numbers refer to the devices that the HDMI cable connects into & NOT the cable itself. The cable simply is a pipeline linking the two. Hence, if you do happen to own a TV and another device that both have HDMI 2.0 ports, any AmazonBasics High-speed rated cable will work perfectly fine with it.** Conclusion **At this price point, there is very little reason to spend more money on more expensive HDMI cables over these AmazonBasics High-speed cables. If you have a 3D, 4K, HDCP 2.2 or HDMI-ARC compatible device, these High-speed cables will work perfectly fine for you.

reviewTitle: End of the line for overpriced HDMI cables
reviewDescription: THIS.... Is Amazon basics  HDMI cable... and I can say that it is the best quick option for a nice HDMI cable at any length you could need!Let me clear the air on some HDMI misconceptions real quick - HDMI cables have nothing to do with whatever version of HDMI your tv has be it HDMI 1.4 , 2.0 , 2.1 or 2.2 as that is the PHYSICAL port on the tv, soundbar, GPU or what have you - the cable is merely the transporter from one thing to the other and either work or doesn't. There is no need for a higher 'grade' of cable as there is nothing you can do to the cable to make it transmit data better. I am sure that Bestbuy would love to sell you on 1000 reasons their $150 cable makes your colors better, but that is all marketing. This is exactly like charging your phone, the cable doesn't charge your phone faster as it is all in the block plugged into the wall - this is the same principle as the cable is merely passing the data.The non-braided cable and endpiece are really well-constructed out of generic rubber-ish material, they are ever so slightly stiff, but are otherwise perfect for any need you could have! There is no issue slotting them next to each other either as the head of the plug maintains a slim profile.I recommend this HDMI cable to anyone in need of one! The price is unbeatable for an HDMI cable, and you will be wasting your money on anything more expensive as this is about as good as it gets(unless you HAVE TO HAVE a braided cable). Once again another reason to have high expectations from an amazon brand as this is another example of a great Amazon Essentials product!REMEMBER!! Your cable is only as good as your HDMI port, so this cable can do 1080p, 4k and more!

For a long time, I thought my TV had issues with HDMI inputs. My screen would go black for a few seconds every so often while the audio would continue playing. I didn't think it could be the HDMI cable - after all, AmazonBasics is a trusted brand and all modern HDMI cables should be able to handle 4K HDR, and the audio wasn't cutting out. But eventually I replaced the cable with the other one from the 2-pack of 10ft cables I had bought. And just like that my glitches stopped happening.Since one cable works but the other glitches out, I'm going to speculate the manufacturing quality is not consistent. Even though the second cable seems okay, I'm replacing it with a certified premium HDMI cable - both MonoPrice and CableMatters have ones that are not much more expensive than this one.

reviewTitle: Did not work with my 4K HDR TV and player
reviewDescription: I have a Vizio M65-E0 4K HDR TV and an LG UP970 UHD Blu-Ray player, which worked fine with other HDMI cables I had. I bought this AmazonBasics cable (in 10ft length) to replace the existing cable, and when I connected the equipment (the player connected directly to the TV, not going through a receiver) and tried to play a disc I got no picture whatsoever... totally black screen. I then swapped back in the old cable, and it worked perfectly.I have no idea what the cause is... whether these cables are incapable of handling HDR datastreams, or there was some incompatibility with one of the components... but one way or another, this cable did not work at all where another cable worked fine.(Giving it two stars because cable build quality seems good and it may work just fine for other uses... just not for mine.)

reviewTitle: Worked flawlessly for two days, then started to deteriorate.
reviewDescription: My computer, which is hooked up to a tv started having green lines streak across the screen off and on. this got progressively worse until it would happen every few minutes. I then amped down the resolution to 2160px1440p and I saw better results, however even that didn't last long, as the green lines started to appear again. I know this is not the TV because the lines only appeared when hdmi was plugged in and casting onto the TV screen. Got another hdmi cord that can supposedly do 8k, so that would be my recommendation to anyone looking for a cord that can do 4k, shop around and find a better one. Don't trust this cord because it says Amazon Basics.

reviewTitle: You get what you pay for.
reviewDescription: Began having issues with the cord about 3 months after purchase. Using it to connect a second monitor to my laptop. My laptop remains stationary so I do not plug/unplug the cable often. While having multiple screens open, certain portions of my laptop screen will freeze and make it impossible to continue working. I would restart my computer every time. I thought for a long time it was my monitor or my computer malfunctioning. Nope, I learned its the $7 cable. All you have to do is unplug and plug it back in. However, I now have to do this multiple times a day. Would not recommend this cable, especially if you plan to use it with items that are difficult to plug/unplug often.

Be advised that this is a seriously industrial grade wire, which makes it very heavy and difficult to bend. Moreover, one need to consider the potential of damaging the socket that it plugs into due to its excessive weight. I have no idea why they made it, so large, but take that into consideration before you purchase it.

reviewTitle: Depends on your setup and TV resolution...
reviewDescription: We recently purchased a LG OLED UHD TV and Yamaha sound bar for our living room.  Knowing that HDMI cables are not created equal, we decided to try this product since it was less expensive than other 4K cables.  After 2 months or so, the conclusion is that this HDMI cable can't handle the load.  We sometimes (perhaps 4 times an hour) have a screen and sound freeze on the TV.  I had a similar problem with another product on my LG OLED in my basement home theater.  The solution was -- Belkin Ultra HD High Speed HDMI Cable, Optimal Viewing for Apple TV and Apple TV 4K, Dolby Vision HDR.  I purchased another to solve the latest problem.

reviewTitle: Works fine if you only need 3'.
reviewDescription: I've bought some of these at 3', 10', and two at 25'. Only the 3' one has worked. I recently bought a 4K TV and needed a 25' cable to run between my PC and TV. It didn't work so I got another figuring it was a bad cable but the replacement didn't work either. In both cases the signal dropped out constantly and I could not run 4K content at 60hz. Got a cable from Monoprice and it has worked great. It was a bit pricier than these but I'll gladly pay for a product that does what it claims to. The 3' one I got has been fine, but I just tried to use the 10' one for an NES Classic and it too doesn't work. The few times I get a signal it's either audio or video and it drops out frequently.Overall I'm really disappointed and won't be buying anymore Amazon branded cables.

reviewTitle: Doesn't appear to support Dolby Vision
reviewDescription: I know the product doesn't advertise that it supports Dolby Vision, but so many reviewers here do.I own brand new Onkyo TX-RZ620, Apple 4K tv, and Vizio PQ65-F1 which all support Dolby Vision.  When running the test on the Apple TV for Dolby Vision, it fails and Apple TV indicates my cables don't support Dolby Vision.  I checked watching directly from my SmartTV function of the Vizio and it was obvious the visual difference while watching Stranger Things on Netflix 4k HDR.  There was so much more detail in the dark scenes when watching Dolby Vision via Smartcast on Vizio.  I'm leaving open the possibility this is operator error but I'll be purchasing different cords that are certified to work with Dolby Vision and see how that goes.

I ordered these because I was recently got a new receiver which was 4K and I knew I was going to be getting a new TV soon.They worked fine with 1080p but once I got my new TV they would only push 4K HDR for a few days and then I would get a flashing image. I hooked up directly to Tv to confirm there wasn’t a handshaking issue between my Apple TV 4K, Denon Rx, and my TCL tv. Video would pass for a day or two and then would start flashing again.I swapped these out for a another cable and have no problems now.

reviewTitle: Despite its plainness it will display 4k60
reviewDescription: Short review:-Took cables out of box, got them to work with an LG 4k60 TV (55UF6450) plugged into an NVIDIA GTX 960 video card. Only the USB-C port will deliver 4k60 with no issues, and I used this cable (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07RM1KGCT/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1).-Both TVs used were a TCL 43" Roku TV with 4k60 display and an LG 55" "smartTV (runs WebOS so claim is dubious)" The TCL probably runs HDMI standard 2.0a/2.1, the LG came out a year after HDMI 2.0 standards were adopted.-I've only used the cable for one day, will do some gaming via Steam and possibly update this review if I run into problems.

reviewTitle: Amazon Basica true to pattern with reasonable product at a reasonable price
reviewDescription: Amazon Basics is not a brand known for frills, and none are found here. But what you do get is solid construction and the traits that matter: meets the spec and has gold-plated, secure connectors.One of the things that pisses me off about cable makers is they try to sell us all this marketing garbage about low-oxygen Vatican-blessed copper with left-spin neutrons or whatever it is audiofools decided matter this week. They slap on the fancy words then think that means they can charge us Blackrock-house-rental prices for a bit of copper in a bulky jacket and some oversize connectors.You know what *actually* matters when it comes to HDMI cables? Gold plating to avoid oxidized connectors, meeting the specification, and not being so bulky or heavy that physics defeats you. These do that, and have a price tag set by someone not out to rob you.
Recommend.

reviewTitle: Not all cables are the same.  Do your research.
reviewDescription: Ok, here’s our setup: LG 65" 4K OLED TV - TiVo Bolt -  Sony Blu-ray - Samsung SoundbarWhen we bought the TV, we initially bought cables we thought were good quality.  Actually I think we bought them because they were color-coded and we were fishing cables through the walls and that likely clouded our judgement.  Since then we’ve had intermittent “HDMI connection not permitted” errors for no reason, requiring a reset to clear.  We also had picture dropouts any time a static electricity charge was grounded anywhere in the room.  Turning on the gas fireplace would cause a dropout.  Electrical storms in the area would cause a dropout.  We decided to isolate the entire setup with a UPS, which helped quite a bit, but never quite solved the HDMI error.  Research indicated the problem might be the cables and further research indicated the Amazon Basics cables tested well and were highly recommended.It’s the cables, dummy.  The Amazon Basics cables cleared up all the problems.  Wish I had done this sooner.

reviewTitle: Not All It's Cracked Up to Be
reviewDescription: I can't speak for all Amazon Basics HDMI cables, only the one I received. It was apparent the moment I plugged one end of the HDMI cable into the TV that the plug itself was undersized compared to other HDMI cables. It's not what you would call a firm, snug fit. Other cables offer a bit of resistance going in, just enough to demonstrate that this would be a secure connection. The cable I received does not give that feedback. It's in, it's working, but by no means is it a firm, snug, confident fit that one comes to expect in a quality HDMI cable. I'm disappointed and will likely be sending it back. For what it's worth other Amazon Basics products, such as their batteries, are great. But this cable is simply "basic". An apt description.

reviewTitle: Wore out with one month of daily plug use
reviewDescription: I purchased this cable to connect my laptop to an external monitor while creating a home workstation for the pandemic. Although it worked as advertised initially, I prefer to put my laptop away at the end of each day, which involves disconnecting the HDMI cable. Within a few weeks, I noticed that the display on my monitor was prone to strange color shifts and pixelation, which went away when I pinched or adjusted the HDMI plug at its connection to my laptop. Switching the orientation of the cable (so that I'm unplugging and replugging the other, less worn end of the cable, while leaving the delicate end in place on the monitor) helped initially, but the end with loose connections still sometimes leaves me with a weird display on the monitor. This cable should be perfectly adequate for someone who will plug it in and leave it that way (e.g. for a home entertainment system), but I wish I had spent an extra $5 for a more durable cable.

reviewTitle: Amazon Basics high-speed HDMI cable good for missing parts
reviewDescription: This high-speed HDMI cable was not necessary for the new monitor that was ordered at the same time.  Most new products that are of a certain build quality will come with a decent HDMI cable for most uses. While this cable is higher speed, the monitor that it will be used for may not have a noticeable effect.

HDMI connection works as is should, easy connection, good picture!  Its a touch bulkier that other brands, but the only tricky part was getting it through wall.  After that the price savings is well worth it.

reviewTitle: Works... pay attention to the plug in direction
reviewDescription: It would be nice if there was the direction arrows on the cord. It's a one direction cord. When I plugged it in to my laptop to mini projector the first time nothing happened. So I switched the plug and then it works, which means it only communicates the HDMI feed in one direction so you have to pay attention to what is being plugged into what. If it doesn't work the first plug in, switch it around and it should work fine.

I had bought these to replace my older AmazonBasics high speed cables (10.2Gbps), however after purchasing a XBOX One X, those cables would not allow the XBOX to work in 4K. I had a similar issue with my Roku Ultra which would not work with the 4K 60fps setting. I decided to try these as they are rated at 18Gbps. While the first cable I tried worked flawlessly (no artifacts, flickering or other issues), the other two did not work as well. I tried Twisted Veins HDMI cables as well and had similar issues. I finally picked up Monoprice cables and haven't had any problems. Most people have good luck with these cables in shorter lengths (6ft or less), however at 10ft or longer I recommend looking for something else if you are using these on a 4K display. The two issues I saw with these cables at 4K 60fps were sparkles or repeating signal loss.

reviewTitle: Beware of picture quality in longer length cables
reviewDescription: I purchased a 25' cable and at fist it seemed to work well enough.  Then during a certain movie with a dark scene, I could barely see the picture.  At first I thought it was because the room was too bright.  Later on during the same movie the screen would go blank for 1-2 seconds every 20-30 seconds.  I ejected the disc and wiped it off but the screen was still flashing.  I had never observed this before but began to suspect the cable.  So I moved the DVD player next to the TV with a shorter cable and the problem went away.  I replaced the 25' cable with an Audioquest Pearl cable (I know, expensive) and the dark scene I couldn't see before was perfectly clear and visible even in the bright room.When researching on-line, many articles say cables need to achieve a speed of 18 Gbps.  The Amazon basics cables claim a speed of "up to" 18 Gbps even for the 25' cable.  I don't think they're getting there.  The Audioquest cables say "exceeds" 18 Gbps.  I never would have guessed it but you can tell the difference and it's significant.

The cables were fine for roughly 3 months, and unfortunately the return window was only 1 month.  Signal to the external monitor stopped working for BOTH of the cables at essentially the same time.  I confirmed that the cables were at fault by swapping them both in and out against a third cable to determine that it was not the monitor or the laptop at fault.The issue was signal degradation, as far as I can tell.  Both cables were causing significant occurrence of vertical lines appearing, and an offset image on the monitor.

reviewTitle: Bad roll of the dice on this HDMI cable
reviewDescription: Unfortunately, I got unlucky with this 25ft cable. Can't hold a 4k 60z signal. Keeps blinking in and out when I hook up my PC to my UHDTV. It seems to work fine with any signal other than that though, so if you are in the market for a long 1080p cable (maybe even 4k 30hz?), this will do fine.Why do I know it's the cable? I tested my system with a shorter high speed hdmi cable I have, and my signal was perfect, even after hours of use. Of course, that meant I had to temporarily move my PC next to my TV to test, which is not a set up I want to keep, otherwise I wouldn't have bothered with a long cable such as this.I don't really blame Amazon that much though. The longer an hdmi cable is, the higher the risk of a bad one. If you really want to be a bit more sure when buying these types of cables, I would look into buying a certified one - a bit more expensive, but you lessen the chance of the cable not performing to what you expect, since those tend to be tested.

reviewTitle: could just be unlucky and I got a pi** poor made cable
reviewDescription: 5 months old, and already one cable has failed, surely it can't be the cable, they are new, so i checked everything else it could be, nope still no signal coming from cable box to the tv, so just for s**ts and giggles I tried another cable.... well look there, tv is receiving a signal / picture, tried the replaced cable on the dvd player, now no signal from dvd player,(yup, cable is bad) so i have 2 six foot cables and one 10 foot cable ... all Amazon Basics HDMI cables, 10 foot one was ordered to run thru the wall (project that I have not started yet) and now I won't be using the brand, could just be unlucky and I got a pi** poor made cable, but not gonna take the chance with using these on my wall project (running cables hidden) you get what you pay for, so that is my fault, Amazon does and has a lot of good things, maybe they should leave the HDMI cables to other manufacturers, I also replaced my Toslink with the Amazon brand.... fingers crossed that it doesn't die also

reviewTitle: Warning! Do Not Use with AppleTV 4K Dolby Vision!
reviewDescription: These cables do not consistently work with the Apple TV 4K with Dolby Vision enabled on my brand new 55" LG OLED B8.  I bought three of them to replace an old Insignia HDMI cable that was not rated for HDMI 2.0.  The new cables needed to be routed through my entertainment system which is time consuming.  It wasn't until after I'd routed the cables that I discovered through a great deal of testing that only 1 of the 3 cables functioned with Dolby Vision enabled on my Apple TV 4K.  The funny part is the old Insignia cable that was not rated for Dolby Vision 4K worked flawlessly with the Apple TV 4K in Dolby Vision mode.  I should have never replaced the Insignia cable!  These cables seem fine for regular 4K and I'm leaving them in since it's too much hassle to replace them in the install and send them back.  It's unlikely that I'll need more than 1 Dolby Vision enabled device in the future, thankfully.  Don't buy if you're using an Apple TV 4K in Dolby Vision mode, some of them do work but it's not worth gambling on these.
It worked great when I first used it then started flickering the picture and then eventually never came back on

I rearranged my desk and needed a slightly longer HDMI cable to go between a PC and a 2015 Samsung 4K TV.  Unfortunately, this cable failed to perform as advertised.  I tested several output modes from the PC, and these are the results.4K 60hz 4:4:4: Fail (Video corruption or "No Signal")4K 60hz 4:2:2: Fail4K 60hz 4:2:0: Success4K 59hz 4:4:4: Fail4K 50hz 4:4:4: Fail4K 30hz 4:4:4: SuccessHDMI 2.0 supports all of those modes.  The two that succeeded are supported by the older HDMI 1.4 standard.  Therefore, I can only conclude that this cable meets HDMI 1.4 requirements but not HDMI 2.0 requirements.To be fair, I got the same results with 4 out of 6 older cables I tried.  The 2 cables that worked (among them, an older style 6 foot AmazonBasics!) are both too short for my desk arrangement.Update (Sept 20, 2016): I found a 10 foot cable that works perfectly for 4K 60hz 4:4:4.
Im always having to adjust the cable with my PC, should have paid for a better one

I had this cable (AmazonBasics High Speed HDMI Cable 6 ft.)  for just under a year. Didn't use it all that often. Wouldn't say I even averaged out to once a month. I started having trouble with it about a week before hitting the one-year mark. When I hook it up to my computer, the image that comes up on the t. v. is distorted (lots of static). I've tried it several times just to be sure.  I live alone. No one else uses it but me, and I take good care of my stuff. Very disappointed in this product.  I gave it two stars only for the little while out of which I got some use.

Tried to save a little money and use this cable with my 144 hz Aorus monitor. From time to time I would see streaks flashing horizontally across the monitor. Did all the usual things; troubleshoot the monitor, make sure I had the most recent drivers for my GPU, tried tweeking the overclocking on the GPU, etc. It kept getting worse. Finally I unplugged the HDMI cable and plugged it back in and shazzam problem disappeared, mostly. It still comes back and reseating the cable makes it go away. Even the orientation of the cable as in it exits the GPU or the monitor a little to the right or left makes a difference. So I am replacing it with a higher quality cable. So I basically wasted the $7

reviewTitle: Wouldn't connect laptop to new 4K television.
reviewDescription: Didn't work properly as description suggested. I attempted to connect a laptop to new Samsung 4K television and no "source" was recognized. I replaced this cable with a SecurOMax 15 foot cable and it works perfectly. I connected to the same locations on each device and in the same order. I had the exact same problem with a 3 foot version of this cable a few months ago and used a SecurOMax version as a successful replacement back then as well. Something else surprising was how thick this cable is compared to shorter ones and how stiff it is compared to the replacements I purchased. It would have been a challenge to make tight turns to hide the cable.  I'm giving 2 stars for great pricing and b/c I've been extremely satisfied with all other AmazonBasics products.

Edit: One of the 2 cables stopped working after the first day. It was fine the first time I played a movie, but the next day when I turned on the blu-ray player, it showed the blu-ray logo on screen for a second then went black and the signal cut out. No matter how many times I unplugged and plugged everything back in, it did the same thing. I switched over to the other cable and that one seems to be working.Original review:I bought a 2-pack and I've only used one so far but it works flawlessly connecting my Sony blu-ray player to my Samsung HDTV. The cables are sturdy, well built and easy to bend.
This HDM lasted less than a year. Next time buy a thicker one to make it worth it.

reviewTitle: Doesn't work when playing old pc games on windows 10
reviewDescription: After a couple of months of usage, I just found out that these cables doesn't work when I'm playing old games. I have Windows 10 and in order to play older pc games, the display usually has to be switched to compatible mode (less color depth and less resolution), but I'm getting a black screen from these cables, and I couldn't even shut off my monitor due to this. I'll have to unplug and power cord and plug it back in to get the monitor to display normally again.I have tried both cables in the package and both have a same behavior. This is bad.

reviewTitle: Quality has dropped since 3 years ago
reviewDescription: I have two of these cables: one from December 2015 and one from now (December 2018). I had been using the old one to send sound from my TV to my receiver with HDMI ARC, and it was working perfectly. After I swapped the new one in for the old one, I started getting skips in the audio signal every couple of minutes. If I put the old cable back, the skips stop.The new cable has different connector molding and is noticeably thinner than the old one, so something has clearly changed in the production process. Maybe the new one has less shielding, leading to this issue?

reviewTitle: the cable stopped working soon after use
reviewDescription: the cable stopped working soon after use. I wrote the seller asking for a replacement and never heard back.

reviewTitle: Can only get sound on one show at a time!
reviewDescription: Been having an issue getting sound over my smart tv. I can only watch one Hulu series at a time. Try to watch another i get either no sound or only music and no voices. Getting angry!

I hooked it up to my Xbox 1 and it will not work. I swapped another HDMI cable from my PC to my Xbox and it worked fine. Im not sure if this is truly "High-Speed" as it claims, but regardless, it wouldnt work for the xbox.

They most likely dont have the Console output settings to HDR or upscaling.I tested this with two cables. 1. The Cable the PS4 Pro comes with (HDMI).  2. And this Amazon Basic cable.The PS4 Cable works.Again, this Amazon Basic cable doesn't work for HDR. I bought this in 2016.

Got it into place and 24 hours later it stopped working.  Had to get my son under my desk to look at it but somehow even tho it was working fine for over 24 hours, the connectors were so fragile that they bent just installing it.Terribly disappointing.

So it’s priced so low that I decided to purchase this “high speed” hdmi cable 3pack. Alas! Only 1 cable actually wors Not purchasing anything from “amazon basics” again! Branding suits it well— BASIC!

reviewTitle: Spend a dollar or two more
reviewDescription: I have bought a number of these, maybe 9 or so. They seem to always fail. I've had to rewire my entertainment system many times to root out which cable is dead, nearly always it's one of these. It has to do with the "handshake" that HDMI uses. I get an active signal, but no picture /sound, or an intermittent flash off and on of the signal. I do not advocate buying expensive HDMI cables, just not these. Go to monoprice.com for cheap cables. Luckily, I keep a handful of HDMI on hand for rewiring, I'll never buy these again. Just spent 2 hours swapping cables tonight after 12 hours on my feet working retail... Amazon, get a better supplier, these are not good.

This was a used HDMI cable. I should have known better. It transmits no signal at all, but the ones I already own transmitted perfectly on the exact same devices. Took to Kohls for return, then a UPS storefront, but they couldn't handle the return. Wound up paying more in gas trying to return this dead cable cost, so just gave up.

reviewTitle: Does not work with Amazon FIRE and Sharp TV
reviewDescription: I'm a big fan of Amazon cables and batteries so the last thing I decided to try when my brand new Amazon Fire box didn't work out of the box was swap my brand new Amazon HDMI cable with a different brand and then "wa-la" it worked perfectly. I tried this cable with my laptop and a different (Samsung) TV which worked fine so the cable is not DOA, it's just something weird about the Fire box and my TV which doesn't seem to be an issue with my other cable. Reading other comments it seems like these cables sometimes have issues. Very disappointed that I can't rely on the Amazon brand.

reviewDescription: When I first got this, i was so excited! I thought it was worth the money and it worked perfectly. Unfortunately after less than a month, it just stopped working. I tried to see if it was just the device I was using but it wasn’t, I tried it with other devices... and still a no go. I didn’t even have it bent or anything. I recently purchased the FOCUS Power headphones and am already experiencing poor quality sound and Bluetooth connectivity issues. It sometimes takes several attempts before the headphones connect to my iPhone and I can literally walk maybe 2 feet away from my phone and will lose the connection. In addition to the connectivity issue, the volume quality is poor in that it sometimes doesn’t increase/decrease when adjusting it. Overall, very disappointed in the poor quality/performance. I’m planning to replace the headphones very soon before they completely die on me.

reviewTitle: Stopped working after the first year
reviewDescription: I have to agree with several other reviewers. This cable (I bought 25') worked great for awhile, but after about a year it started working only intermittently. I wasted tons of time troubleshooting the problem, not knowing the cable was to blame. Finally I gave up and ordered a Power Bear HDMI cable. Problem solved instantly. Thus I cannot recommend this product.

reviewTitle: You get what you pay for
reviewDescription: I had consistent pictures issues and had to unplug and plug these back in a few times a week to get them to work. Switched to better cables and the problem went away

Be aware that these cables are extremely thick, I mean ridiculously thick. If they were listed as "Heavy Duty" or something similar, that would be fine and I would have chosen something else.These were a nightmare trying to do any type of cable management. Ended up throwing them to the side and using normal gauge HDMI cables to run my dual computer monitors. They also put a lot of pressure on the HDMI port that you are plugging into.

reviewTitle: Great initially, but didn't last long
reviewDescription: I bought this cable and then actually bought it again a few weeks later. Everything seemed okay, but then they both failed on different devices months later right about the same time. I had one connected to a TV and the other connected to a monitor and they both died out in the same week. You get what you pay for, I guess.

I tried a Blu-ray player and had the same issue. I ended up ordering a fiber optic hdmi cable and that solved my problem. It will allow one or the other to be used (or both duplicated, which is useless). Other high-speed HDMI cables that I have will allow the displays to be extended, i.e. as soon as I connect a different cable I can view both screens as one desktop, so this is an issue with this cable specifically. If you need to drive roughly two 4K displays, don't buy this cable.

Buy this cable if you have a desire to buy another one in less than a year.  Minimal usage and no wear and tear, but second monitor started blinking and had red dots.  Had a 5 yr old HDMI cable at home that I plugged in and problem solved.  Don't waste your money on this or be fooled by the Amazon endorsement.
Everything is great until it just stops working. First one failed after about 4 months, the second one failed after about 5 months. Will definitely not buy this again.
Works as expected

After keeping my ps4 slim stored away I realized I was missing my HDMI cable and decided to order this. Turned out to be perfect and of better quality than the original HDMI cable that was included. Would recommend as a replacement.

Bought in an emergency because I needed a cable quickly. Quality is as to be expected. Would not hesitate to recommend this as a lower to middle end solution for cables. It is as flexible as most other cables. Cable gauge seems to be adequate for video feeds. Picture quality is fine. The length is good too. Installation was a breeze. Connector fit in to the HDMI port as it should.

reviewTitle: Thick & stiff (in 25' length), but this one actually works!
reviewDescription: After trying a couple of other cheap 25' HDMI cables with poor results (one failing to work at all, the other only at low resolutions like 480p), I looked for the thickest reasonably-priced cable I could find, using the HDMI connector as a scale reference in photos.  The body of this cable is about 4 times thicker than my others. It pushes perfect video & audio from my HTPC to a television in another room, even with an HDMI "splitter" (distribution amp) on the source end, and a 3-to-1 source switch on the receiving end, both of which weaken the signal somewhat.  I'm only using it at 1080p/60Hz, though, the limit of that remote TV, which is less demanding than the specified 4k resolution.  Its thickness makes this cable more difficult to run, but at these lengths that's a necessary trade-off when pushing distance limits, just based on the physics of signal transmission. A thinner cable of equal performance would need to use fiber optics, or active in-line amplification, either of which will increase the cost, and add additional powered electronics that could fail in the future.The 25' version of this cable is marked 24AWG, meaning its individual wires inside are equal in thickness to those of a typical Cat5e or Cat6 cable.  I cut open & stripped my off-brand, non-working-even-at-480p 25' cable to compare, and estimate the width of its individual conductors (within one of the 4 twisted-pairs) to be 30 AWG at best, possibly even thinner.  (Larger AWG = American Wire Gauge numbers mean thinner wires... it's one of those weird upside-down scales).  Size matters!  Shorter cables in this listing do appear to be thinner, which is fine at those lengths, so long as you don't try to chain several of them together.

reviewTitle: There is DEFINITELY a need to buy more expensive HDMI cables (for 4k@60Hz)
reviewDescription: Despite being advertised as supporting 4k @ 60Hz, connecting my new Intel 7th gen NUC computer (HDMI 2.0) to my LG OLED TV (HDMI 2.0) caused blank screen/ audio dropouts every few seconds. This occurred for both the cables in the twin pack across all 4 TV HDMI input ports, suggesting a physical design shortcoming rather than an isolated quality problem.  Replacing this cable with the one that came with my PS4 Pro resolved the problem.In summary, works fine for connecting lower resolution/lower refresh rate devices (computer 4k @ 30Hz or 1080p @ 60Hz), but doesn't cut it for ultra high bandwidth HDMI 2.0 connections. Comments such as Oliver T. "And as the highest resolution any 4K TV currently on the market can produce is 3840 x 2160 at 30fps" are inaccurate so watch out - this experience has demonstrated that there is indeed a need to buy more expensive HDMI cables if you want to run at 60fps (60Hz).Trying these ones next - hoping they perform better

reviewTitle: Not Acceptable for 4k HDR/Dolby Vision with a Reciever
reviewDescription: So I always though that HDMI cables were all the same. I was wrong. Although these cables are marked high speed they did not work in my setup. I have a Vizio M65-E0 TV, Onkyo TX-NR575 Receiver, Apple TV 4k and Xbox One S. With these cables hooked up my Xbox One S would not recognize my TV as being 4k HDR  and the Apple TV 4k would not allow Dolby Vision. The receiver can pass HDR and Dolby Vision and my TV is capable of both as well. I also had issues displaying anything from the Xbox that was not 1080p such as DVDs etc. I was very frustrated and spent hours swapping settings and resetting all my gear. I finally decided to try some different cables. I purchased the Monoprice Certified cables also available on Amazon. Voila, everything was perfect. If you are looking to get 4k HDR or Dolby Vision out of your home theater setup passing through a receiver, I would recommend you steer clear of these cables and get the Monoprice Certified. They are only a few dollars more and much higher quality.

reviewTitle: This cable does not work with Roku Premere+/Ultra and Samsung KS8000 in 4K HDR mode.
reviewDescription: Bought 6ft version on Dec 2016 for my new Samsung 65 inch KS8000 (late 2016 model) and Roku Premere+.  This cable does not work in 4k HDR mode.  I kept getting HDCP purple screen error with Amazon and Google play apps on Roku.  After a lot of research on the Internet I found out if I disable HDR and use only 4k output mode on Roku, HDCP errors go away.  So HDR was causing HDCP negotiation to fail.  This is one workaround i discovered.  Then I tested an old HDMI cable i bought from Monoprice 8 years ago for the heck of it.  Turns out this old cable works reliably in 4k UHD HDR mode.  The old cable from Monoprice looks more like an old VGA cable with feritte cores on each ends of the cable.  So days of all generic high speed  hdmi cable being equal are over with 4k HDR.  People are discoving hard way that compatability issues are caused by HDMI cables with HDCP 2.2 and 4K HDR signalling.  Gone are the days when any generic hdmj cable just works.  This is probably a welcomed news for price gauging cable upsellers like Monster and best buy sales guys.

reviewTitle: I wasted about an hour trying to make the cable work ...
reviewDescription: I ordered the two pack version to use them with a Samsung JS9000 48" SUHD TV and a Mac Mini and a PC.  I wasted about an hour trying to make the cable work with a Nvidia 980Ti in native 4K resolution(3840 x 2160)/60Hz/RGB(4:4:4)/Full Output dynamic range, but no matter what I tried, the TV would only display full resolution/color at 30Hz.  Worse, setting inputs as HDR would detect no signal from the video card at all.On a whim, I tried a no name cable lying around that I thought I had purchased as a HDMI 2.0 compliant cable, and all of sudden I was able to set my resolution to full 4K/60Hz/RGB/Full dynamic range, as can be seen in the included screenshot.  The resulting clarity with the HDMI 2.0 compliant cable was stunning.Since it's been more than 30 days (took so long to try these cable since my first shipment was damaged during transit, and had to return the first order), I can no longer return the cable, but for anyone considering using the cables with a 4K TV in its native resolution + HDR + 60 Hz + 4:4:4, I highly recommend staying away from this cable.

Bought this to replace the power cord for my Dell laptop. Worked great for about 6 months until today. It's still lights up on the end but My laptop was not charging. Thought maybe it was the laptop port but it wouldn't charge my phone either.

reviewTitle: Will not work for sound bar to smart tv
reviewDescription: This will not work with my Samsung smart tv and Sony sound bar. The sound bar originally came with a small thin optic wire that wasn't long enough. I should be able to use an HDMI cord. But a message pops up on the TV that says to plug it into HDMI3 since it's arc also. But that's what port its plugged into!! And it won't work. Returning since this is the only reason I bought it. The TV is only a few weeks old so it can't be the TV.

Good value for good cables
We used this as a replacement we needed for the Switch dock to TV. This has done a great job at first plug in…cord length, picture and connection is fantastic still.

The AmazonBasics HDMI cord delivers reliable performance and durability at an affordable price. It supports Ethernet, 3D, 4K video, and Audio Return Channel (ARC), making it a versatile choice for various home entertainment setups. Its build quality is commendable for the price, offering a sturdy connector and a flexible, yet durable cable sheath. Ideal for users seeking a cost-effective solution without compromising on essential features and quality.

reviewTitle: Great quality and easy to use
reviewDescription: Used this cable to connect a somewhat older monitor to my desktop. Works as intended and is high quality.
Needed to connect a laptop on a desk to a monitor on the wall.  This was a good length.  Works great.
Works great.
This HDMI long wire works very well long enough so I could have the other room and have the wire go through the walls to the TV perfect I would recommend this if you need a 50+ HDMI wire very thick

reviewTitle: Stopped working a little less than 1 year
reviewDescription: I have several HDMI cables and this is the first to stop working within a year. This is also the newest HDMI cable I purchased and the only one that has stopped working. Will not be replacing with another Amazon basics product.

reviewTitle: As thick as an outdoor extension chord and as stiff as a garden hose. Not usable with a laptop.
reviewDescription: This cable is as described in the heading. I was shocked at how "fat" the cable is, and how stiff it is. I have numerous other HDMI cables of varying lengths, although none are this long, however all are of the same "capacity" and all are much thinner and more flexible. I had intended to use it between my laptop and HD TV so I can use the TV as a monitor, however it  is impossible to use with a laptop because it is way too "heavy" and stiff, and it is impossible to coil and stow behind the TV when not in use. There is nothing in the description which alerts you to the "thickness" of the cable so now I am somewhat apprehensive about purchasing a different "brand" because I don't want anything like this again. Although I don't need an ultra-thin cable, I assume that's the only way I can be assured that I will be getting something "workable".

I've tried pretty much every combination of source/TV I have, but I continue to get no signal through these cables (I'm on my second set) when using any hardware that outputs a 4K signal.My 4K hardware consists of a Sony UHD Blu-Ray player, a Roku Ultra Box, and X-Box One S. When cables are attached to any of these devices and connected to EITHER a 4K television or a 1080P-only set, no signal is transmitted. When the cables are connected to a regular Blu-Ray player (both a Sony and LG) or a non-4K streaming box (WDTV Live), the signal passes through. It also passes through an old Acer Revo Windows PC. But 4K? Not on your life. My previously purchased cables from Monoprice work just fine with all the hardware mentioned above.Since I bought it for 4K use, it gets one-star. If you want it for 1080P stuff, grade it higher.
This lasted all of 2 months. The picture started glitching in and out. I changed the HDMI cord and haven’t had a problem since.

reviewTitle: WiFi devices Showed No Inter-Connection with Wired Ethernet Receiver after Using These Cables
reviewDescription: I Exchanged these cables for my "non-ethernet" HDMI cables attached to my LG OLED TV and Comcast Box, along with Apple TV, Samsung Blu-ray 4k player, and Xbox X. attached to my Yamaha AV Receiver.  I have only one ethernet cable attached to my AV receiver and these cables were advertised to extend to other devices without needing an ethernet cable on each one.  Well, I got only static on my Blu-ray player and my Apple TV which was working perfectly the night before the exchange suddenly stopped working no matter what I plugged into it (which may be a coincidence, but...who knows?).  And as for ethernet connectivity, well, the devices attached to my AV receiver (which is wired) still only recognized connection via my WiFi network.  In summary, the cables did nothing for network speed or connection, and in at least one case (the Samsung Player) would not even work as a typical HDMI cable.

After reading reviews here to confirm that these cables are 4K HDR10 capable, I ordered a set of three to run in the wall between various devices and a new LG 4K tv.  They work fine with regular HD devices, but connected to an Xbox watching 4K Netflix, they fail within a few seconds every time.  It'll show a few seconds of the video, flicker to static for a second, or show noise patterns, then go blank.  Switching back to the HDMI cable that came with the Xbox works flawlessly.  All three cables exhibit this problem, so this doesn't seem to be a one-off issue.The Xbox renders all its menus and other output at 4K all the time, but the only time the cables fail is when Netflix enables HDR10 (the tv shows a little HDR badge in the corner when this happens), so I'm assuming the incompatibility is with HDR10.

reviewTitle: I bought 2 of these and had the same problem ...
reviewDescription: I bought 2 of these and had the same problem with both. You either get no picture or a very red striped or pixelated picture not clear enough to make-out or watch. It isn't enough of a connection to provide a signal so it goes in and out. We used one in our bedroom and kept having problems with the connection. We thought it was the Roku or the power supply and replaced both. We eventually quit using the Roku thinking it just wasn't going to work. We used the other in our game room to attach an extra gaming system to the TV. Apparently it has never worked - I just thought my kids preferred the other games. When I realized their's hadn't worked either I tried a cable from our cable box and both my Roku and their gaming system worked perfectly. Since they were both used on "extra" electronics, I didn't realize they weren't working in time to return them.
This cable continues to disconnect from monitor even after a small vibration, which indicates it is not a tight fit. As a result the cable does not serve its purpose.
Tried to hook up between my phone and my monitor in my RV prime would have none of that

I ordered a 3 pack of the AmazonBasics “High Speed” HDMI Cables, 10 ft. Upon receiving, I plugged in my Xbox One X with the new cable, but nothing displayed. After troubleshooting, I determined it was the cable. The cable would pass 1080p signal, but when changed to 4K from the Xbox One X, it would no longer display.Of the box of 3, 1 HDMI cable properly displayed the 4K HDR content. I called Amazon and they sent me out a replacement set of 3. When I tested these 3 cables, NONE of them worked.Of the 6 cables I received, ONLY ONE worked as advertised, the other 5 were all defective.I should note that I am an “IT guy” and know my way around electronics. From my experience, AmazonBasics should be avoided for High Speed HDMI purposes, unless you are ok with a 16.6% success rate.

reviewTitle: Beware of the Fine Print (False Advertisement)!!
reviewDescription: I’ll start by stating that I LOVE AMAZON!!! However, I’m disappointed in this product. Amazon needs a spanking for this one! Amazon Basics describes this product as a “High-Speed 4K HDMI 10ft Cable.” Well, they got the attributes right, except for the part about 4K. All quality HDMI cables will have fine print written on their exteriors. This “fine print” usually lists all the cable’s specs, informing the consumer of what the product is and what it isn’t. This particular cable is no exception. Its fine print is VERY detailed and makes absolutely NO MENTION of 4K! It’s a high quality cable, but it isn’t 4K (it’s just a standard cable). If it matters to you (like me) that the cable be 4K, this isn’t your product! However, if 4K doesn’t matter to you, then I’d recommend it. In conclusion, If 4K quality matters, keep looking; this isn’t what you want!!
It worked okay for a few weeks until the screen started blacking out every few seconds. I went through the troubleshooting steps but nothing worked.

I got this product maybe a year ago for my gaming monitor don’t really use my pc and randomly I got on my pc and the cord was burn out the metal input was charred and I was wondering why my monitor wasn’t working or turning on mind you I have two monitors smh never getting this again.

Amazon Basics High-Speed HDMI Cable, 1.4B Male to Male, 18 Gbps, 4K/60Hz, 15 Feet, White.Used for traveling presentations. Used periodically for a couple of months. and picture quality was good.  About 3 months old it stopped working.

reviewTitle: Cable didn't work with basic monitor
reviewDescription: Not all cables are created equal. I used this cable on a new Acer monitor which supports a native resolution of 1920x1080 @60hz. The best of would do was 800x600 @50hz. Once I changed cables to something else, problem solved. Unfortunately, I have to point the finger at the cable in this case. Bad cable, cable design not 100% too spec? I don't know, unfortunately I don't have time to process a return. I just need something that works.

reviewTitle: Not compatible with AppleTV 4k running a 4K, 60Hz signal
reviewDescription: Unfortunately, this cable does not function properly with the AppleTV 4k running at 4K, 60Hz with Dolby Vision connected to an LG C7P TV. Other cables from other manufacturers do work. Apple recommends the Belkin Ultra High Speed HDMI cable, which is not sold in lengths longer than 2 meters.Initially, this cable did pass the cable-check feature of the Apple TV, but then the picture would intermittently be lost while watching shows using various apps like Hulu and YouTube. The behavior exhibited when the signal was lost is similar to what you see when you use a cable that you know not to work (I know because that is where I started).  Substituting a shorter modern HDMI cable (one that shipped with the HTC Vive VR set) worked fine.I don't know whether any 10 feet cable will work using a 4k signal from the Apple TV. I have instead purchased Apple's recommended cable (2x the price for 1/2 the length) and plan to mount the Apple TV behind the TV set. The AppleTV is pretty small - that will work.

reviewTitle: 25 feet cable - No go for 4k 60hz 4:4:4 chroma during 02-10-2017.
reviewDescription: 25 foot cable- what a POS. Apparently they're 'under review' & not available at the moment or something to that effect.1st cable- No signal2nd cable (replacement)- No signal when connected in one direction. When swapped end-for-end, green dots all over the screen.Setup was a PC + 4K + Amazon basics latest version 25 foot cable. Bought it due to the good reviews, would recommend trying a different cable atm. I'm assuming there was a manufacturing defect or bad batc etc. The Best Buy Insignia 8' cable is working fine with the same setup, still looking for a longer cable. Seen recommendations for Monoprice, & KabelDirekt. Crapshoot.It may be adequate for 1080p, or lower quality resolutions, but the item is described as: "4K Video at 60 Hz, 2160p, 48 bit/px color depth) that supports bandwidth up to 18Gbps" which is the reason for the 1 star review. I'd give it 0 if possible. If it met those specs it would be a good buy.tags- 25', 25 foot, 25 feet, 4k 60hz 4:4:4 chroma, 4k 60hz 444 chroma
The picture was not clear and was not bright compared to the original HDMI cable that came with the LG 34” screen. I returned it for a refund the same day I received it.

Bought cable in 2020 and rarely used it in our finished basement. Recently started to use the basement and the TV would not connect to source. After trying several devices like Apple TV, DVD player and cable box, found out that the cable itself was bad.

Purchased a bundle of 3 in early 2018. They look well made but do not seem to last. Two of them been plugged to a TV, Nintendo Switch and nVidia Shield TV. Both of the cables stopped displaying any signal after about 2 years.Pinpointing the issue the first time was frustrating, the one on the Switch failed first and a couple of hours were spent fiddling with the dock, the TV, the switch and a computer monitor to rule things out. The cable is pretty much the last thing you would expect to fail out of the blue. Once it failed with the Shield TV it was quicker to figure out the culprit after the previous experience.As for the third cable, it mostly sits in a drawer but it still works. At this point I would suggest getting something more robust and avoiding the potential time spent troubleshooting and replacing cables down the line.
